PREFACE
This code of the City of Artesia, as supplemented, contains ordinances up to
and including ordinance O-1135, passed August 13, 2024. Ordinances of the City
adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to the
extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the City
office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has
been amended, superseded or repealed.
America Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not affect the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 659
   AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING
   THE ARTESIA, NEW MEXICO CITY CODE
   BE IT ORDAINED by the mayor and city council of the city of Artesia, New
Mexico, as follows:
   Section 1. From and after the date of passage of this ordinance, the city
code of the city of Artesia, New Mexico, prepared by Sterling Codifiers, Inc.,
containing the compilation of all ordinances of a general nature together with
the changes made to said ordinances, under the direction of the governing body
of the city, shall be accepted in all courts without question as the official
code and law of the city as enacted by the mayor and city council.
   Section 2. There is hereby adopted, as a method of perpetual codification,
the loose-leaf type of binding together with the continuous supplement service,
provided by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., whereby each newly adopted ordinance of a
general and permanent nature amending, altering, adding or deleting provisions
of the official city code is identified by the proper catchline and is inserted
in the proper place in each of the official copies, one copy of which shall be
maintained in the office of the city clerk, certified as to correctness and
available for inspection at any and all times that said office is regularly
open.
   Section 3. All ordinances of a general nature included in this official city
code shall be considered as a continuation of said ordinance provision and the
fact that some provisions have been deliberately eliminated by the governing
body shall not serve to cause any interruption in the continuous effectiveness
of ordinances included in said official city code. All ordinances of a special
nature, such as tax levy ordinances, bond ordinances, franchises, vacating
ordinances and annexation ordinances shall continue in full force and effect
unless specifically repealed or amended by a provision of the city code. Such
ordinances are not intended to be included in the official city code.
   Section 4. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to
change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such code, or
to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such
code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be
misrepresented thereby.
   Section 5. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith, are,
to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed.
   Section 6. This ordinance and the code adopted by the same shall be recorded
and shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval
as provided by law.
   Section 7. The effective date of this ordinance and the code adopted by the
same shall be January 1, 2003.
   PASSED, ADOPTED AND APPROVED this 10th day of December, 2002.
                                                                  
                     Daniel Reyes, Mayor
ATTEST:
                                           
Barbara Kilough, City Clerk
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL CITY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon the adoption by the city council, this city code is hereby declared to be
and shall hereafter constitute the official city code of Artesia. This city
code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the ARTESIA MUNICIPAL CODE and
is hereby published by authority of the council and shall be supplemented to
incorporate the most recent legislation of the city as provided in section
1-1-3 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this city code by title in any legal documents. (2002 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
The city code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of this
state as the ordinances of the city of general and permanent effect, except the
excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (2002 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending the city code shall set forth the title, chapter and
section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to
the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this city code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers, and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this city code. Each such replacement page
shall be properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of
the city code. (2002 Code)
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this city code in such a manner that the
meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Said code, while in
actual possession of officials and other interested persons, shall be and
remain the property of the city and shall be returned to the office of the city
clerk when directed so to do by order of the city council. (2002 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Ways And Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
   A.   Ordinances Repealed And Ordinances Saved From Repeal: All general
ordinances of the city passed prior to the adoption of this city code are
hereby repealed, except such as are included in this city code or are by
necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving
clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the following
ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances; appropriation
ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations; franchise
ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or
corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances
establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places;
improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections;
ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the
city; and all special ordinances.
   B.   Limitations On Repeal: The repeal of the ordinances, as provided in
subsection A of this section, shall not affect any debt or fee which is
accrued, any duty imposed, any penalty incurred, nor any action or proceeding
commenced under or by virtue of the ordinances repealed or the term of office
of any person holding office at the time these ordinances take effect; nor
shall the repeal of any ordinance have the effect of reviving any ordinance
heretofore repealed or superseded. (2002 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC WAYS AND PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroad crossings with streets and other public ways,
or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities shall
be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this city code or by virtue of the
preceding section, excepting as the city code may contain provisions for such
matters, in which case, this city code shall be considered as amending such
ordinance or ordinances in respect to such provisions only. (2002 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Prior Acts: No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a
former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not,
as to any offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act
done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued
or claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect
any such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment may be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
   B.   Extend To All Repeals: This section shall extend to all repeals, either
by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making
any new provisions upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   C.   Current Pending Actions: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be
construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general
ordinance of the city herein repealed, and the provisions of all general
ordinances contained in this code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions
and not a new enactment of the same provisions; nor shall this chapter be
deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or
to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm or corporation, or
as waiving any right of the city under any ordinance or provision thereof in
force at the time of the adoption of this city code. (2002 Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase
of this city code or any part thereof is for any reason held to be
unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of
the remaining portions of this code, or any part thereof. The city council
hereby declares that it would have passed each section, subsection,
subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase thereof irrespective of the
fact that any one or more sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs,
sentences, clauses or phrases be declared unconstitutional, invalid or
ineffective. (2002 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Interpretation; Construction Of Words
1-3-2: Definitions, General
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: INTERPRETATION; CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
   A.   Construction Generally: The provisions of the ordinances and all
proceedings under them are to be construed with a view to effect their objects
and to promote justice. (1996 Code § 1.04.080)
   B.   Interpretation Of Language: All words and phrases shall be construed
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate
meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar
and appropriate meaning. (1996 Code § 1.04.030)
   C.   Gender; Singular/Plural: Whenever any word in any section of this city
code importing the plural number is used in describing or referring to any
matters, parties or persons, any single matter, party or person shall be deemed
to be included, although distributive words may not have been used. When any
subject matter, party or person is referred to in this city code by words
importing the singular number only, or a particular gender, several matters,
parties or persons and the opposite gender and bodies corporate shall be deemed
to be included; provided, that these rules of construction shall not be applied
to any section of this city code which contains any express provision excluding
such construction or where the subject matter or context may be repugnant
thereto.
   D.   Interpretation Of Certain Words:
      1.   Ordinance: The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the
city has been changed in the content of this city code to "title", "chapter",
"section" and/or "subsection" or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to the city's ordinances is not meant
to amend passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (2002 Code)
      2.   Agents: When an act is required by this city code, the same being
such that it may be done as well by an agent as by the principal, such
requirement shall be construed to include all such acts performed by an
authorized agent. (1996 Code § 1.04.050)
      3.   Prohibited Acts: Whenever in this city any act or omission is made
unlawful, it shall include causing, allowing, permitting, aiding, abetting,
suffering or concealing the fact of such act or omission. (1996 Code §
1.04.060)
   E.   Computation Of Time: Except when otherwise provided, the time within
which an act is required to be done shall be computed by excluding the first
day and including the last day, unless the last day is Sunday or a holiday, in
which it shall also be excluded. (1996 Code § 1.04.070)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS, GENERAL:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code, they shall have
such meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another with authority conferred, either
expressly or by implication.
CITY: The city of Artesia, county of Eddy, state of New Mexico, or the area
within the territorial limits of the city, over which the city has jurisdiction
or control by virtue of any constitutional or statutory provision.
CODE: The city code of the city of Artesia.
COUNCIL: Unless otherwise indicated, the city council of the city of Artesia,
New Mexico. "All its members" or "all council persons" means the total number
of council persons holding office. The words "city council" shall mean the
"governing body of the city".
COUNTY: The county of Eddy, state of New Mexico.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city employee by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Artesia".
GENDER: A word importing either the masculine or feminine gender only shall
extend and be applied to the other gender and to persons.
GOVERNING BODY: The city council composed of the mayor and the council members.
LAW: Denotes applicable federal law, the constitution and statutes of the state
of New Mexico, the ordinances of the city of Artesia, New Mexico and, when
appropriate, any and all rules and regulations which may be promulgated
thereunder.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MAY: Is permissive.
MONTH: A calendar month.
MUST, SHALL AND WILL: Are each mandatory.
NMSA: New Mexico Statutes Annotated.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive to the sensibilities of reasonable persons, or any
act or activity creating a hazard which threatens the health and welfare of
inhabitants of the city, or any activity which by its perpetuation can
reasonably be said to have a detrimental effect on the property of a person or
persons within the community.
OATH: Includes an affirmation or declaration in all cases in which, by law, an
affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear"
and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed".
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with
others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Artesia".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of
such building or land.
PERSON: Includes a natural person, joint venture, joint stock company,
partnership, association, club, company, corporation, business, trust,
organization, or the manager, lessee, agent, servant, officer or employee of
any of them.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall include every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
PRECEDING AND FOLLOWING: Next before and next after, respectively.
PROPERTY: Includes real and personal property.
REAL PROPERTY: Includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things direct to the consumer.
RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other
property.
SIDEWALK: That portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent
property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
STATE: The state of New Mexico.
STREET: Includes all streets, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts, places,
squares, curbs or other public ways in the city which have been or may
hereafter be dedicated and open to public use, or such other public property so
designated in any law of the state.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with others.
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall
be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things
to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law to any official or public writing or bond, it shall be in the proper
handwriting of such person or, in case such person is unable to write, by such
person's proper mark.
YEAR: A calendar year. (1996 Code § 1.04.010; amd. 2002 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of the city code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
division or section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or
reenacted. (2002 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Suspended Sentences; Probation; Community Service
1-4-3: Mandatory Fees
1-4-4: Petty Misdemeanors; Citations
1-4-5: Application Of Provisions
1-4-6: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
   A.   Definition:
      1.   In this section, the expression "violation of this code" means any
of the following:
         a.   Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an
offense or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by
ordinance.
         b.   Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by
ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance.
         c.   Failure to perform an act if the failure is declared a
misdemeanor or an offense or unlawful by ordinance or by rule or regulation
authorized by ordinance.
      2.   In this section, "violation of this code" does not include the
failure of a city officer or city employee to perform an official duty unless
it is provided that failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided
in this section.
   B.   Penalties Designated:
      1.   Except as otherwise provided, a person convicted of a violation of
this code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars
($500.00), imprisonment for a term not exceeding ninety (90) days, or by both
such fine and imprisonment. With respect to violations of this code that are
continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate
offense.
      2.   The penalty for violations of an ordinance prohibiting driving a
motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs shall
be a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment for
not more than one hundred seventy nine (179) days, or both.
      3.   The penalty for violations of an industrial user wastewater
pretreatment ordinance as required by the United States environmental
protection agency shall be a fine of not more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) a day for each violation.
   C.   Effect Of Penalty: The imposition of a penalty does not prevent
revocation or suspension of a license, permit or franchise or other
administrative actions.
   D.   Continuous Violations; Nuisance Declared: Violations of this code that
are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by
injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty, however,
does not prevent the simultaneous granting of equitable relief in appropriate
cases. (2002 Code)
1-4-2: SUSPENDED SENTENCES; PROBATION; COMMUNITY SERVICE:
   A.   Upon a plea of guilty or a judgment of conviction for violation of any
provision of this city code or any city ordinance, the municipal court may
suspend in whole or in part the execution of sentence or place the defendant on
probation for a period not exceeding one year on terms and conditions the court
deems best, or both.
   B.   Suspension of execution of the sentence or probation, or both, shall be
granted only when the municipal judge is satisfied it will serve the ends of
justice and of the public.
   C.   The defendant's liability for any fine or other punishment imposed
shall be fully discharged upon successful completion of the terms of probation.
   D.   The municipal court may, as a condition of probation, require the
defendant to serve a period of time in volunteer labor to be known as community
service. The type of labor and period of service shall be at the sole
discretion of the court; provided, that any person receiving community service
shall be immune from any civil liability other than gross negligence arising
out of the community service, and any person who performs community service
pursuant to court order or any criminal diversion program shall not be entitled
to any wages, shall not be considered an employee for any purpose and shall not
be entitled to workers' compensation, unemployment benefits or any other
benefits otherwise provided by law. As used in this section, "community
service" means any labor that benefits the public at large or any public,
charitable or educational entity or institution. (1996 Code § 1.16.020)
1-4-3: MANDATORY FEES:
   A.   Corrections Fee:
      1.   Fee Established: Any person convicted of violating any provision of
this code or any city ordinance, the penalty for which carries a potential jail
term, or any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle shall pay
to the municipal court, in addition to any fine or other sentence, a twenty
dollar ($20.00) corrections fee. (Ord. 663, 6-10-2003, eff. 7-1-2003)
      2.   Disposition Of Funds: All money collected pursuant to this
subsection shall be deposited in a special fund in the municipal treasury and
shall be used only for municipal jailer training, the construction planning,
construction, operation and maintenance of the municipal jail, for paying the
costs of housing the city's prisoners in other detention facilities in the
state or for complying with match or contribution requirements for the receipt
of federal funds relating to jails. (1996 Code § 1.16.030)
   B.   Judicial Education Fee:
      1.   Fee Established: Any person convicted of violating any provision of
this code or any city ordinance, the penalty for which carries a potential jail
term, or any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle shall pay
to the municipal court, in addition to any fine or other sentence, a three
dollar ($3.00) judicial education fee. (Ord. 822, 8-25-2009)
      2.   Disposition Of Funds: All money collected pursuant to this
subsection shall be remitted monthly to the state treasurer for credit to the
judicial education fund and shall be used for the education and training,
including production of bench books and other written materials, of municipal
judges and other municipal court personnel. (1996 Code § 1.16.040)
   C.   Court Automation Fee:
      1.   Fee Established: Any person convicted of violating any provision of
this code or any city ordinance, the penalty for which carries a potential jail
term, or any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle, shall pay
to the municipal court, in addition to any fine or other sentence, a six dollar
($6.00) court automation fee, to be effective July 1, 1998.
      2.   Disposition Of Funds: All money collected pursuant to this
subsection shall be remitted monthly to the state treasurer for credit to the
municipal court automation fund and shall be used for the purchase and
maintenance of court automation systems in the municipal courts. The court
automation system shall have the capability of providing, on a timely basis,
electronic records in a format specified by the judicial information system
council.
      3.   Application Of Provisions: All other sections of this code which are
affected by this subsection shall be deemed to include the proper increase in
court costs brought about by the change in the court automation fee. (Ord. 596,
5-12-1998)
1-4-4: PETTY MISDEMEANORS; CITATIONS:
   A.   Intent And Purpose: This section is intended to provide an alternative
to the arrest and incarceration of persons committing petty misdemeanor
offenses under the laws of New Mexico or the city. This section is deemed
necessary to preserve peace and order in the city and protect and promote the
property, health and welfare of the city and its inhabitants. (1996 Code §
1.12.010)
   B.   Conduct Of Arresting Officer; Notices By Citation:
      1.   Citation Offered: Whenever a person is arrested without a warrant
for any violation of city or state law which is punishable as a petty
misdemeanor, the arresting officer may offer the arrested person the option of
accepting a citation to appear in court in lieu of being retained in custody
pending such appearance.
      2.   Contents Of Citation: A citation issued pursuant to this section
shall contain the name and address of the arrested person, the offense charged,
and the time and the place for the person to appear in court. Unless the person
requests an earlier date, the time specified for appearance shall be at least
five (5) days after issuance of the citation. The law enforcement officer shall
explain the person's right not to sign the citation, the effect of not signing
the citation, the effect of signing the citation, and the effect of failing to
appear at the time and place stated on the citation.
      3.   Signature; Disposition Of Copies: The person's signature on the
citation constitutes his written promise to appear at the time and place
specified in the citation. A copy of the citation shall be delivered to the
person cited, and the person shall then be released from custody. The original
of the citation shall be filed with the municipal court as soon as practicable.
      4.   Effect: A citation issued pursuant to this subsection is a valid
complaint, though not verified, in the event the person receiving it
voluntarily appears in court. (1996 Code § 1.12.020)
   C.   Violation; Penalty: Any person's violation of his written promise to
appear in court at the time and place specified in the citation shall
constitute a petty misdemeanor offense punishable by a fine of not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for not more than ninety
(90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, regardless of the disposition
of the charge for which the citation was issued. (1996 Code § 1.12.030; amd.
2002 Code)
   D.   Procedure Not Exclusive: This section governs all municipal police
officers in making arrests without warrant for petty misdemeanor violations of
the laws of New Mexico or the city, but the procedure described in this section
is not exclusive of any other method allowed by law for the arrest and
prosecution of a person violating these laws. (1996 Code § 1.12.040)
1-4-5: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: The penalty provided in this chapter shall be
applicable to every section of this city code the same as though it were a part
of each and every separate section.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this city code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but
not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same
offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be
considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this city code
and there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach,
the provisions of this chapter shall apply. (2002 Code)
1-4-6: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this city code designating the duties of any officer or
employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for
any fine or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the
intention of the city council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (2002 Code)
CHAPTER 5
CITY OFFICERS
SECTION:
1-5-1: Elective Officers
1-5-2: Appointive Officers
1-5-3: Salaries
1-5-1: ELECTIVE OFFICERS:
The elected officers of the city shall be a mayor and two (2) council members
for each of the four (4) districts 1 . Such elective officers shall constitute
the city council and in it shall vest all corporate authority of the city.
(1996 Code § 2.04.010; amd. 2002 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 8 of this title for election provisions.
1-5-2: APPOINTIVE OFFICERS:
   A.   Officers Designated: The appointive officers of the city shall be the
city clerk, city treasurer, police chief, and such other officers as the city
council shall authorize from time to time by resolution.
   B.   Offices Combined: The city council may combine any appointed offices as
necessary for the efficient operation of city government or in the best
interest of the city. The titles of the combined appointive offices shall be
done by resolution.
   C.   Deputies: The city council may provide for deputy appointed officials
who may exercise the powers granted the appointed officials.
   D.   Contract: The city council may fill by contract any of the appointed
offices as necessary for the efficient operation of city government or in the
best interest of the city. (Ord. 740, 11-14-2006)
1-5-3: SALARIES:
The monthly compensation of the mayor, mayor pro tem, and members of the city
council shall be as follows:
 
Position          Monthly Compensation
                            
Mayor                       $25,000
Mayor pro tem               15,000
Members of the city council 12,500
 
(Ord. 717, 10-25-2005; amd. Ord. O-1121, 12-12-2023)
ARTICLE A. CITY ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-5A-1: Appointment And Term
1-5A-2: Powers And Duties
1-5A-3: Compensation
1-5A-1: APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
The mayor shall nominate and the city council shall appoint a city attorney who
shall remain in office until a successor is appointed. (1996 Code § 2.08.010;
amd. 2002 Code)
1-5A-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Attend Meetings; Opinions: It shall be the duty of the city attorney to
attend all regular and special meetings of the city council and to prepare
written opinions upon all legal questions submitted to him by the council, when
requested. He shall also attend, when requested, the meetings of any committee
of the city council and shall advise any such committee upon all questions of
law submitted to him, and when so requested, he shall advise any and all city
officers upon all questions of law pertaining to the duties of any such
officer. (1996 Code § 2.08.020; amd. 2002 Code)
   B.   Draft Legal Instruments; Legal Advisor: The city attorney shall draft
all ordinances, contracts, leases, conveyances and other instruments of writing
which may be required of him by the city council members. He shall act as legal
advisor of the city on all questions pertaining to contracts with or by the
city and shall advise upon all questions of law in regard to same. (1996 Code §
2.08.030; amd. 2002 Code)
   C.   Right To Be Heard: The city attorney shall have the right to be heard
upon all questions or motions before the city council amending, repealing, or
in any way affecting any ordinance in force or to be enacted by the city
council when the legality of such action or proposed action shall be called in
question. (1996 Code § 2.08.040; amd. 2002 Code)
   D.   Prosecutions: It shall be the duty of the city attorney to prosecute in
municipal court all persons charged with violating the city ordinances or any
part of them. He shall also, when requested by the city council or any officer
duly authorized to make the request, appear in behalf of the city in all suits
or proceedings by or against the city in any court wherein the same may be
pending or about to be instituted by the city, and prosecute or defend the
same, as the case may require. He shall cause executions to be issued on all
judgments in favor of the city and attend to their prompt collection. (1996
Code § 2.08.050; amd. 2002 Code)
   E.   Execution Of Bonds Or Affidavits: The city attorney is authorized and
empowered to make and execute any bond or affidavit in the name of the city of
Artesia, signing the same as city attorney, that may be necessary in any suit
or proceeding in which the city is a party. (1996 Code § 2.08.070)
1-5A-3: COMPENSATION:
The city attorney shall receive such compensation as the council by vote may
determine. (2002 Code)
ARTICLE B. MUNICIPAL JUDGE
SECTION:
1-5B-1: Election And Term
1-5B-2: Qualifications
1-5B-3: Oath Of Office
1-5B-4: Vacancy In Office
1-5B-5: Bond And Salary
1-5B-6: Monthly Report
1-5B-7: Annual Training
1-5B-8: Fines And Costs
1-5B-9: Temporary Municipal Judge
1-5B-1: ELECTION AND TERM:
The municipal judge shall be elected, for a term of four (4) years, at a
regular municipal election. (2002 Code)
1-5B-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The municipal judge shall be a qualified elector of the city and an actual
resident within the city limits. He shall be over the age of twenty one (21)
years and have at least the equivalent of a high school education. (1996 Code §
2.12.010)
1-5B-3: OATH OF OFFICE:
The municipal judge shall take an oath or affirmation to support the
constitution of the United States, the constitution and laws of New Mexico and
to faithfully perform the duties of his office. (2002 Code)
1-5B-4: VACANCY IN OFFICE:
The governing body may fill a vacancy by appointment of a municipal judge to
serve until the next regular municipal election. (2002 Code)
1-5B-5: BOND AND SALARY:
   A.   Bond: The municipal judge shall, before entering upon the duties of his
office give bond to the city in the amount of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00).
(Ord. 716, 10-25-2005)
   B.   Salary: The salary for the municipal judge of the city shall be sixty-
five thousand dollars ($65,000) per annum.
   C.   Hours: The municipal judge shall devote full time and attention to the
office, including such hours on weekends and holidays as may be necessary, in
order to fully and efficiently discharge the duties of such office as they may
be set forth under the law of the United States, the state of New Mexico and
the ordinances of the city. The municipal judge shall preside over the hearings
at every stage of any proceeding concerning violation of this code or any other
ordinances of the city. The municipal judge shall comply with the code of
judicial conduct and all rules of procedure for the municipal courts as
promulgated by the state supreme court.
   D.   Benefits: The municipal judge shall receive all other employment
benefits which are extended to municipal employees and which are not
inconsistent with the municipal judge’s elected status. (Ord. 716, 10-25-2005;
amd. Ord. 775, 9-25-2007; Ord. 990, 1-12-2016; Ord. O-1122, 12-12-2023)
1-5B-6: MONTHLY REPORT:
   A.   Required: The municipal judge is required to make a monthly written
report to the city council of all monies collected by him which belong to the
city. Such report shall be filed with the city clerk on or before the tenth day
of each month after such funds are collected by the municipal judge. (1996 Code
§ 2.12.020)
   B.   Contents: The report required of the municipal judge by subsection A of
this section shall include an itemized statement showing the different amounts
so collected, the purpose for such collection, the names of the persons from
whom such collections were received and the date such funds were received by
the municipal judge. (1996 Code § 2.12.030)
1-5B-7: ANNUAL TRAINING:
The municipal judge shall undergo annual training, as required by New Mexico
Statutes Annotated section 35-14-10, unless exempted by the chief justice of
the state supreme court, as a prerequisite to drawing his salary. (2002 Code)
1-5B-8: FINES AND COSTS:
   A.   Assessment Of Costs: In all cases tried in the municipal court of the
city, where the defendant enters a plea of guilty or there is a conviction on a
plea of not guilty, costs shall be assessed against and collected from the
defendant in accordance with the laws of New Mexico. (1996 Code § 2.12.040)
   B.   Disposition Of Fines And Costs: All fines and costs collected by the
municipal judge in cases in the municipal court shall be paid by the municipal
judge to the city clerk at least once each month, and the city clerk shall
furnish the municipal judge with a written receipt of such fines and costs
paid. (1996 Code § 2.12.050; amd. 2002 Code)
1-5B-9: TEMPORARY MUNICIPAL JUDGE:
   A.   Appointment: Upon recusal or disqualification of a duly elected
municipal judge as may be required or permitted by law, or if by reason of
absence, sickness, or incapacity, a duly elected municipal judge is temporarily
unable to perform his official duties, a temporary municipal judge shall be
appointed to perform such official duties during the period of temporary
incapacity or inability. The temporary municipal judge shall be designated and
appointed by the municipal judge. In any case where the municipal judge fails
to appoint a temporary judge, a temporary judge can be designated and appointed
by the mayor with the concurrence of the governing body. (1996 Code § 2.12.060;
amd. 2002 Code)
   B.   Qualifications: Any person who is a registered voter of and actually
resides within the city limits and who otherwise meets the minimum
qualifications required by ordinance for an elected municipal judge may be
appointed. (1996 Code § 2.12.060)
   C.   Oath: Before entering upon the discharge of his duties, the temporary
municipal judge shall give oath of office as is required by ordinance for an
elected municipal judge. (1996 Code § 2.12.060; amd. 2002 Code)
   D.   Powers And Duties: The temporary municipal judge shall hear and
determine cases arising under the ordinances of the city, and he shall have all
powers, responsibilities and authorities granted or required of the duly
elected municipal judge according to law. (1996 Code § 2.12.060)
   E.   Compensation: A temporary municipal court judge shall receive a salary
for the performance of his official duties. The salary shall be proportionately
based upon and shall not exceed the salary provided by ordinance for the duly
elected municipal judge. (1996 Code § 2.12.070)
CHAPTER 6
EMPLOYEE PRACTICES AND REGULATIONS
SECTION:
1-6-1: Title; Legislative Authority
1-6-2: Scope And Applicability
1-6-3: Equal Opportunity Statement
1-6-4: Recruitment, Application And Hiring Process
1-6-5: Classification
1-6-6: Changes In Employment Status
1-6-7: Performance Appraisal
1-6-8: Disciplinary Actions
1-6-9: Grievances
1-6-10: Criminal Charges And Convictions
1-6-11: Termination, Demotion, Suspension Of Employment
1-6-12: Prohibited Activities
1-6-13: Performance Standards
1-6-14: Position Classification Plan
1-6-15: Exempt Or Nonexempt Status
1-6-16: Leave Policy
1-6-17: Department Rules
1-6-18: Personnel Records
1-6-1: TITLE; LEGISLATIVE AUTHORITY:
This chapter shall be known as the CITY OF ARTESIA PERSONNEL ORDINANCE, and the
city council adopts this chapter pursuant to New Mexico Statutes Annotated
section 3-13-4. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
1-6-2: SCOPE AND APPLICABILITY:
   A.   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all persons employed by
the city, except as follows:
      1.   Professional consultants.
      2.   Independent contractors.
      3.   Temporary employees.
      4.   Part time employees working less than seventeen (17) hours per week.
      5.   All employees in the municipal court department.
      6.   All elected officials. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
   B.   Appointive officers of the city as designated by section
1-5-2 of this title report directly to the mayor. With the exception of
subsections 1-6-4A, B and C3; section
1-6-5; subsections 1-6-6A, B and D; sections
1-6-8 and
1-6-9; subsections 1-6-11A, B, C, D, E and F; 1-6-14B, C and D; and 1-6-15A,
this chapter shall apply to appointive officers.
   C.   With exception only to subsections 1-6-11G and H of this chapter,
appointive officers designated by section
1-5-2 of this title shall not be entitled to the rights and procedures set
forth in section
1-6-11 of this chapter.
   D.   If an appointive officer is employed under a separate employment
contract, then all terms and conditions of employment are governed by and shall
be stated in the contract. (Ord. 721, 2-14-2006)
1-6-3: EQUAL OPPORTUNITY STATEMENT:
It is the policy of the city that equal opportunity shall govern in all
personnel policies and practices and shall include, but not be limited to:
   A.   Recruitment, hiring and promotion of any qualified person on the basis
of merit without regard to race, creed, color, religion, ancestry or national
origin and without regard to age, sex or physical or mental disability except
where such is a bona fide occupational qualification.
   B.   Employment and promotion in accord with the principles of equal
employment opportunity and affirmative action based on only valid job
requirements.
   C.   Personnel actions such as compensation, benefits, transfer, layoff,
reinstatement, training, and social and recreational programs administered
without regard to race, creed, color, religion, ancestry, or national origin,
or to age, sex or physical or mental disability except where such is a bona
fide occupational qualification. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd. 2002 Code)
1-6-4: RECRUITMENT, APPLICATION AND HIRING PROCESS:
   A.   Recruitment And Application Procedure:
      1.   It is the intent of the city to fill vacancies on the basis of
relevant criteria believed to be essential to the selection of the best
qualified applicant. When a vacancy occurs, the mayor's office will be notified
immediately. Upon the mayor's instruction, the human resources director will
prepare and post a notice in all departments. The notice will state the
position, the basic requirements of the position including minimum experience,
skills and knowledge, and/or training required, the salary range, and how and
when to apply. The posting will last five (5) working days from the
announcement to allow all employees the opportunity to respond. (Ord. 661, 4-
22-2003)
      2.   Additional applicants from outside the city employee ranks may be
solicited through the department of labor, newspaper and/or other advertisement
methods. Applicants will be required to complete an application and provide all
requested information and references. When in the city's best interest,
preference will be given to a qualified internal applicant versus an outside
applicant. However, the city reserves the right to solicit and hire outside
applicants at any time, for any position. Only qualified applicants will be
given the courtesy of an interview.
   B.   Selection Process:
      1.   The selection process may require interview(s), preemployment skills
and knowledge testing, and drug and alcohol screening.
      2.   Preemployment testing may be required by supervisors, to screen
qualified applicants. Physical examinations and drug and alcohol screenings
will be required for all candidates prior to employment, but only after a
conditional offer of employment is made. Psychological testing will be required
for all police and fire department candidates prior to employment, but only
after a conditional offer of employment is made. Cost for physical
examinations, drug and alcohol screening and psychological tests will be paid
by the city.
      3.   At the conclusion of the selection process, the department head and/
or immediate supervisor will recommend a candidate for the mayor's approval.
The mayor will make an appointment for hiring, subject to the approval of a
majority of all members of the governing body.
   C.   Hiring Requirements:
      1.   Driver's License: A valid, New Mexico, properly classed driver's
license may be a job qualification for employees of the city. If, after hiring,
an employee fails to maintain a valid driver's license, immediate notification
to the employee's supervisor is required.
      2.   Certifications: Certain positions of the city require a
certification by state authorities, including, but not limited to, water and
wastewater ( 2 years for 1 year rule will apply with appropriate proof of
experience and level of certification for exempt and nonexempt applicants.
Following the Comp Study pay scale pay will be capped at Step 10 ), law
enforcement, and fire/EMS. However other positions have levels of certification
within the profession that may be required by the city.
      3.   Ineligibility: Any applicant for employment with the city may be
disqualified from gaining such employment and any city employee's employment
may be terminated if that person:
         a.   Lacks minimum qualifications, including certification status;
         b.   Is below the legal minimum age for employment in the position
applied for;
         c.   Does not complete the application; (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
         d.   Does not comply at all times with any residency requirement(s)
which may be found in any existing city resolution, or city job description for
that position, or any applicable city contract; (Ord. 729, 6-13-2006)
         e.   Is unwilling to undergo a background and reference check, if
required;
         f.   Fails to meet statutory requirements on clearance from felonious
or infamous crimes;
         g.   Is not bondable and the position requires a bond;
         h.   Is shown to have wilfully provided false information on an
employment application, resume or other city document;
         i.   Is shown to have acted fraudulently in conduct in connection with
an employment examination; or
         j.   Refuses to submit, cooperate, or complete any medical examination
duly authorized to be administered by a licensed physician at city expense.
(Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
      4.   Employment Of Relatives:
         a.   Definition: "Relative" is defined as spouse, child (including
step), brother/sister (including step and in-law), parent (including step and
in-law), aunt, uncle, nephew, niece, grandparent or grandchild.
         b.   Prohibitions: The city may not hire, promote or transfer
relatives of city employees (as defined above) when such action violates any of
the following terms:
            (1)   Relatives (as defined herein) shall not report directly to
the same supervisor or department head. This includes work assignments in which
employees are rotated. Furthermore, no employee shall occupy a position which
reports directly to a "relative" (as defined herein) or a position where a
"relative" (as defined herein) supervises the employee's supervisor. It is
preferred that relatives not be permanently assigned to work locations where
they are physically close to or in view of each other.
            (2)   The provisions of this policy shall apply when employees
marry. The employees shall notify their immediate supervisor(s) within five (5)
working days when a violation of this policy occurs due to marriage. When
marriage results in a violation of this policy, one of the employees may
transfer to a position that does not violate this subsection, if the employee
proves to be the best qualified candidate through the interview process. If no
such vacancy exists, one of the employees must terminate his/her employment
within a period of three (3) months. The married employees shall choose which
employee will transfer or terminate his/her employment. If the married
employees cannot reach an agreement, the mayor, upon the recommendation of the
human resources director, will make the decision with the approval of the
governing body.
         c.   Confidentiality: Department heads and supervisors shall establish
safeguards to prevent situations in which an employee possesses or has access
to sensitive paperwork or other communications regarding a relative.
         d.   Temporary Employees: The mayor, with the approval of the majority
of the governing body, may from time to time authorize the employment of
temporary employees who are relatives of existing employees. (Ord. 622, 11-28-
2000)
      5.   Citizenship Verification: The city will not discriminate on the
basis of a person's national origin or citizenship status with regard to
recruitment, hiring or discharge. However, the city will not knowingly employ
any person who is, or becomes, an unauthorized alien. In compliance with the
immigration reform and control act of 1986, all employees hired after November
6, 1986, must provide suitable documentation. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd. Ord.
O-1112, 6-27-2023)
1-6-5: CLASSIFICATION:
   A.   Probationary Period:
      1.   A probationary period is used to provide an adequate period of time
to effectively evaluate an employee's ability to function in a position.
Employees required to complete the probationary period include: (See #8 for
Fire and #9 for Police)
         a.   Newly hired employees;
         b.   Newly transferred employees;
         c.   Newly promoted employees;
         d.   Newly demoted (voluntary or involuntary) employees;
         e.   Employees renewing employment after a fully terminated absence of
sixty (60) days who have not served more than one hundred eighty-three (183)
calendar days commencing or renewing employment.
      2.   The probationary period shall begin on the date of assignment and
shall continue for six months for all new hires. The department head or
supervisor will complete monthly written reviews of progress up to completion
of 6 months. All written reviews will be turned into HR for placement in
employee’s file.
      3.   An employee may be discharged during the period with or without
cause. A letter of discharge will be provided by the Mayor or his/her designee.
      4.   All probationary employees are eligible for health insurance
benefits, retirement benefits, sick leave benefits and annual leave.
      5.   A probationary employee may not apply for a transfer or promotion to
another department until successfully completing his/her probationary period.
      6.   If any employee transfers, or is promoted to a different position,
within the same department while on probation, a new six (6) month, one hundred
eighty-three (183) day probationary period shall begin effective with the date
of assignment.   
      7.   A probationary employee may only transfer or be promoted once during
a six (6) month period.
      8.   Fire personnel requiring Academy training and certification will
serve a one (1) year probationary period from date of hire. Any fire applicants
who have already completed full certification and are entering as lateral
applicants will be subject to the six (6) month probationary period.
      9.   Uncertified Police officer will have a probationary period of six
months following the completion of all conditions of hire (physical/
psychological screenings, successful completion of the basic police academy
training and the successful completion of the Field Training Officer program).
PD/Cadet must obtain dated certificate stating Cadet’s status to Certified
Police Officer on day of Academy graduation and turned in to HR for promotional
immediate processing status to Certified Police Officer.
      Certified officers and officers who are accepted by the State of New
Mexico DPS Training Center to attend the certification by waiver will have a
six (6) month probationary period after successful completion of the Field
Training Officer Program.
      The certification by waiver employee will still be required to
successfully complete the certification by waiver course as a part of the
conditions of hire, even if the course is taken at the end of a probationary
period due to availability of the training.
   B.   Regular Employees: Regular employees are those employees who have
successfully completed the required probationary period. Regular employees may
be suspended, demoted or dismissed only for cause, subject to hearing before
the Governing Body, and are eligible to use the grievance process. Regular
employees are entitled to a complete benefit program, including retirement,
life and health insurance, sick leave accrual and annual leave.
   C.   Regular Full Time Employees: Regular full time employees are those who
have successfully completed the probationary period and whose regular workweek
equals or exceeds thirty five (35) hours per week.
   D.   Regular Part Time Employees: Regular part time employees are those who
have successfully completed the probationary period and whose regular workweek
is less than thirty five (35) hours per week. Employees hired to work more than
seventeen (17) hours per week are eligible for all benefits provided regular
full time employees, or as established by any other section of this chapter.
   E.   Temporary Employees: Temporary employees may be either full or part
time depending on the position being filled regardless of hours worked, but are
considered temporary employees if the work being performed has a specific
duration, not to exceed nine (9) consecutive months, such as employment during
peak periods, summer, and students under vocational education programs.
Temporary employees have no benefits and may be terminated with or without
cause. Department heads may recommend a termination, subject to the approval of
a majority of the members of the Governing Body. (Ord. 647, 3-12-2002; amd.
Ord. 1077, 11-24-2020; Ord. O-1112, 6-27-2023)
1-6-6: CHANGES IN EMPLOYMENT STATUS:
   A.   Transfer: Transfer is when an employee is moved voluntarily or
involuntarily from one position to another position within the same pay grade.
The employee receiving a transfer shall continue to receive the same base pay
rate. An employee shall apply for a vacancy for a voluntary transfer.
   B.   Promotions: Promotion is when an employee is moved from one position to
another position with a higher maximum pay grade and greater responsibility;
the employee will receive an increase in pay of 6% or the entry level of the
new position in relation to the new Comp Study pay grade scale, whichever is
greater. To be promoted, the employee must be upgraded in pay. An employee
shall apply for the vacancy.
   C.   Salary Increases: Employees are eligible for salary increases through
the pay classification plan established by the Governing Body.
   D.   Demotions: Demotion is when an employee is moved voluntarily or
involuntarily from current position to another position due to performance
duties outlined in Job Description. The salary of an employee who is demoted
voluntarily or involuntarily shall be placed at a lower pay grade and step that
falls within the 6% range of the current pay scale. A demotion (voluntary or
involuntary) dictates that an employee must be downgraded in pay. The effective
date of the salary reduction will be the first day of the next pay period
following demotion. An employee initiating a voluntary demotion shall apply for
a vacancy and must have a recommendation by the mayor and approval of the
governing body. All other demotions shall follow procedures as set forth in
subsection 1-6-11 D of this chapter. (Ord. 848, 11-23-2010; amd. Ord. 1016, 10-
10-2017; Ord. O-1112, 6-27-2023)
1-6-7: PERFORMANCE APPRAISAL:
The human resources director, under the supervision of the mayor, shall monitor
the performance appraisal process to assure that each employee, including
supervisors and department heads, are given a properly conducted performance
appraisal at minimum on their anniversary date. Appraisal documentation will be
submitted to HR for placement in employee’s file.
   A.   To understand the level of his/her job performance in relation to
expectation.
   B.   To receive counseling and advice that will assist the employee in
improving current performance and in preparing for greater responsibilities in
the future.
   C.   To address below standard performance and to establish plans for
improvement. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd. Ord. O-1112, 6-27-2023)
1-6-8: DISCIPLINARY ACTIONS:
   A.   Causes: Disciplinary actions, up to and including termination, may be
taken for violations of department rules, regulations or procedures. Violations
of any section of this chapter, shall include, but are not limited to, the
following: (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd. 2002 Code)
      1.   Conviction for violation of any federal, state or city law on or off
the job, which if committed on the job site would adversely affect the
employee's performance in the city service.
      2.   Negligence in the performance of duty, including, but not limited
to, negligence in the operation of city vehicles or equipment.
      3.   Failure to meet prescribed standards of work.
      4.   Unauthorized absence from work, or abuse of sick leave.
      5.   Physical or mental unfitness for duty due to intoxication from
alcohol or drugs or any other cause.
      6.   Insubordination by failing to follow lawful instructions of the
supervisor.
      7.   Falsification of records.
      8.   Misuse, theft or destruction of city property.
      9.   Horseplay that endangers or impedes job performance, or would be an
embarrassment to the city.
      10.   Wilfully falsifying a job application, resume, or any other city
document.
      11.   Interference with others on the job.
      12.   Any other conduct on the job that adversely affects the employee's
ability to perform his/her work, is a danger to others, or impedes the
productivity of others, in the reasonable opinion of the employee's supervisor.
      13.   The dissemination of confidential and personal information related
to or about the city and/or city employees, except as allowed by state or
federal law.
      14.   Failure of a drug and/or alcohol test. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
   B.   Procedures:
      1.   Generally:
         a.   It is important to match the type and severity of disciplinary
action with the inappropriate conduct to be addressed. Some actions may only
require a verbal warning, while others demand suspension, demotion or
termination on the first offense. There are two (2) main factors that should be
considered in determining the need and type of discipline administered.
            (1)   The severity of the offense.
            (2)   The employee's past documented employment record, both
positive and negative.
         b.   For any form of corrective or disciplinary action, proper
documentation must be prepared. Documentation is required to accurately record
the facts of the situation while they are fresh in the minds of all concerned,
in case future reference becomes necessary. All documentation given to an
employee should be signed by the employee to acknowledge receipt. If the
employee refuses to sign, another employee shall be called in to sign the form
and witness the fact that the counseled employee received the documentation but
refused to sign it. The immediate supervisor of an employee or department head
may take appropriate action and maintain written documentation in support of
actions involving informal talks and verbal and written reprimands. Department
heads may recommend suspensions, demotions and terminations.
      2.   Informal Talk: Usually given to employees with good work records who
have broken a minor rule. Employees are advised they have broken a rule and
cautioned against repeating.
      3.   Verbal Reprimand: More severe discussion with employee who has
broken a rule. In this case, the employee is told that his/her behavior must
improve or more serious action will be taken. A record of the discussion will
be placed in the employee's personnel file and the employee is given a copy.
      4.   Written Reprimand: Written reprimands are used for serious offenses
for employees who have broken a rule, regulation or procedure. The written
reprimand should mention prior reprimands given, and specifically describe what
the employee has done wrong. Written reprimands should indicate what
improvement is expected and the time limit in which the improvement should be
made. Written reprimands should state what will happen if the improvement is
not made, and should offer the supervisor's help in bringing about a change in
conduct. The employee receives a copy of this written reprimand, and a copy is
placed in the personnel file.
      5.   Suspension: The mayor may suspend, with or without pay, an employee
until the next regular meeting of the governing body, at which time the
suspension shall be approved or disapproved by a majority of all the members of
the governing body. If the suspension of the employee is disapproved by the
governing body, the suspended employee shall be notified of the ending date of
the suspension and paid the compensation he was entitled to receive during the
time of his/her suspension.
      6.   Demotion: The governing body may demote an employee with the
approval of a majority of all the members of the governing body. The mayor may
demote an employee upon the approval of a majority of all the members of the
governing body. Any regular employee who is demoted shall, upon his/her request
in writing, be given, by the mayor, in writing, a list of reasons for his/her
demotion.
      7.   Termination: The governing body may terminate an employee with the
approval of a majority of all the members of the governing body. The mayor may
terminate an employee upon the approval of a majority of all the members of the
governing body. Any regular employee who is terminated shall, upon his/her
request, be given, by the mayor, in writing, a list of reasons for his/her
termination. Such employee shall also be paid any accrued compensation,
including annual leave, he/she is entitled to receive. (Ord. 691, 9-28-2004)
1-6-9: GRIEVANCES:
   A.   Application And Interpretation:
      1.   The grievance procedure applies to all regular employees who have
completed the probationary period. A grievance is a perceived or actual
misunderstanding or disagreement regarding the meaning, interpretation,
application or alleged violation of this chapter, approved departmental
policies and rules or other administrative policies or a complaint about the
employee's working conditions.
      2.   Supervisors and department heads will comply with these policies and
will deal with employees fairly to minimize or preclude misunderstandings,
problems, complaints or grievances. In the bringing of a grievance at any
supervisory level, employees are assured freedom from restraint, interference,
discrimination or reprisal.
   B.   Procedure:
      1.   The parties should resolve all employee disputes at the lowest
possible level. All unresolved disputes are required to pass through all
appropriate levels of procedures. Disputes concerning the interpretation or
application of a collective bargaining agreement may not utilize this
procedure. An employee with a grievance shall first try to resolve it with his/
her immediate supervisor. If the grievance cannot be resolved to the employee's
satisfaction, the employee shall submit a written grievance to his/her
supervisor.
      2.   The supervisor shall try to resolve the matter with the employee
within five (5) working days from receipt of the written grievance. If the
employee is not satisfied that the grievance was resolved by his/her
supervisor, or if the supervisor took no action within five (5) working days of
receipt of the written grievance, then the employee can appeal the grievance to
the employee's departmental grievance representative by presenting a written
grievance and requesting a grievance committee hearing.
      3.   The departmental grievance representative shall submit this
grievance to the grievance committee at its next meeting. The frequency of the
committee's meetings will be determined by the quantity of grievances.
      4.   Within two (2) weeks of filing the grievance with the grievance
committee, the committee will study the grievance and agree to:
         a.   Deny the grievance; or
         b.   Propose a settlement which will be submitted to the governing
body for approval or disapproval.
      5.   If the grievance committee agrees that the alleged grievance is
justified, the committee will submit to the governing body its findings and the
committee's recommendations at the next scheduled governing body meeting.
      6.   The governing body will study and investigate such grievance and
agree to:
         a.   Deny the grievance; or
         b.   Approve a settlement of the grievance submitted by the grievance
committee. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
   C.   Departmental Grievance Representatives:
      1.   Departmental grievance representatives shall be elected by secret
ballot by the employees of their respective departments/divisions, and they
shall be employees but not supervisors or department heads.
      2.   Duties of the departmental grievance representatives shall be to
select six (6) representatives to serve on the grievance committee and to
submit to the grievance committee grievances filed by the employees of their
respective departments.
   D.   Grievance Committee: There shall be a grievance committee of six (6)
persons, not supervisors or department heads, selected by the departmental
grievance representatives. Of the six (6) employees on the grievance committee,
one shall be selected from the library, airport, museum, commission on aging
and recreation departments, one each shall be selected from the police and fire
departments, and three (3) members shall be selected from the remaining city
departments/divisions. Duties of the grievance committee shall be to study and
investigate grievances submitted to it, and deny the same or propose settlement
thereof to the governing body. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd. 2002 Code)
1-6-10: CRIMINAL CHARGES AND CONVICTIONS:
   A.   Definitions:
   CONVICTION: A final adjudication, by a court of competent jurisdiction, that
the applicant for city employment or the city employee, as the case may be, is
guilty of a criminal act constituting a felony or misdemeanor involving moral
turpitude, and includes both a conviction following trial on the merits and a
conviction based upon a plea of guilty or nolo contendere.
   FELONY: Any criminal act made a felony by the laws of the state of New
Mexico, including criminal acts committed outside the state of New Mexico which
would be felonies in New Mexico, whether or not so classified in the state
where committed.
   MISDEMEANOR INVOLVING MORAL TURPITUDE: A criminal offense, lower than a
felony, involving conduct contrary to justice, honesty, modesty or good morals.
   B.   Requirements On Employment And Applications: An applicant for city
employment shall fill out and sign a written application for city employment
requiring a statement as to whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a
felony or a misdemeanor and requiring the applicant to list convictions. The
applicant may also be required to submit to fingerprinting at the time of
making application. A false answer in the employment application that the
applicant has not been convicted of any felony or misdemeanor and/or failure to
list all such convictions shall be grounds for immediate termination.
   C.   Disqualification For Employment: A conviction of a felony or a
misdemeanor involving moral turpitude shall disqualify an applicant for city
employment and may be cause for termination of city employees, subject to the
right of the governing body to waive the requirement. The governing body may
determine that the requirement is not necessary and that the hiring of the
applicant and continued employment of the city employee will not be detrimental
to the effective conduct of city government. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd. 2002
Code)
1-6-11: TERMINATION, DEMOTION, SUSPENSION OF EMPLOYMENT:
   A.   Layoff: If it becomes necessary to reduce the size of the work force or
to reduce the number of occupants in a particular job classification, the
governing body shall establish guidelines for such a layoff. Names of regular
employees who have been laid off shall be placed on an availability list for
ninety (90) days and shall be informed of any openings that occur during that
time. Laid off employees will be permitted to apply for position openings when
the opening is posted within the city departments. This is the only benefit
granted laid off employees and they shall receive no other benefit or
consideration.
   B.   Involuntary Termination; Termination, Demotion, Suspension: Department
heads are authorized to recommend that an employee be terminated, demoted or
suspended. The mayor may suspend the employee with or without pay, until a
pretermination, predemotion or presuspension hearing is held.
   C.   Pretermination Hearing:
      1.   Time For Hearing:
         a.   The human resources director or mayor's designee will schedule a
pretermination hearing within ten (10) working days of the written notice by
the mayor to terminate an employee. The employee shall be delivered a written
notice of intent to terminate. The notice shall:
            (1)   Cite the specific incidents that indicate just cause.
            (2)   Cite violation of any rule or mandate.
            (3)   Provide an explanation of the documentation, evidence, and/or
factors relied upon by the department head.
            (4)   Specify the proposed disciplinary action.
            (5)   State the date, name, time and place for the hearing to be
held with the employee within ten (10) working days from the date of delivery
of the written notice.
         b.   Upon recommendation of the department head/supervisor, the mayor
may extend the ten (10) working day period prior to the hearing to be held with
the employee. The employee and the human resources director or mayor's designee
may agree in writing to an alternate date, time and/or place for the hearing.
      2.   Hearing Held: The hearing shall be between the employee and the
employee's immediate supervisor and/or department head, with the human
resources director or mayor's designee hearing both sides. This hearing is to
allow the employee to respond to the charges and offer explanations and/or
present witnesses in mitigation of the proposed termination. This is not a
minitrial and there is no right to cross examination.
      3.   Written Decision:
         a.   If a written or oral response to the proposed termination is
offered by the employee at the hearing, the human resources director or mayor's
designee shall consider the response and deliver a written decision on the
proposed action to be taken no earlier than forty eight (48) hours and no later
than five (5) working days following the hearing.
         b.   The written notice of final decision must:
            (1)   Include the date of delivery of the notice of final decision.
            (2)   Address the employee's defenses.
            (3)   Identify the specific incidents showing just cause.
            (4)   Cite the violation of rules or mandate.
            (5)   Specify the final decision including the action to be taken
or dismissal of charges.
            (6)   Specify the effective date of the action.
            (7)   Inform the employee that he/she shall have the right to
appeal the disciplinary action under subsection E of this section.
   D.   Predemotion Or Presuspension Hearing:
      1.   Time For Hearing:
         a.   The human resources director or mayor's designee will schedule a
predemotion or presuspension hearing within ten (10) working days of the
written notice by the mayor to demote an employee or suspend an employee. The
employee shall be delivered a written notice of intent to impose disciplinary
action. The notice shall:
            (1)   Cite the specific incidents that indicate just cause.
            (2)   Cite violation of any rule or mandate.
            (3)   Provide an explanation of the documentation, evidence, and/or
factors relied upon by the department head.
            (4)   Specify the proposed disciplinary action.
            (5)   State the date, name, time and place for the hearing to be
held with the employee within ten (10) working days from the date of delivery
of the written notice.
         b.   Upon recommendation of the department head/supervisor, the mayor
may extend the ten (10) working day period prior to the hearing to be held with
the employee. The employee and the human resources director or mayor's designee
may agree in writing to an alternate date, time and/or place for this hearing.
      2.   Hearing Held: The hearing shall be between the employee and the
employee's immediate supervisor, with the human resources director or mayor's
designee hearing both sides. This hearing is to allow the employee to respond
to the charges and offer explanations and/or present witnesses in mitigation of
the proposed disciplinary action. This is not a minitrial and there is no right
to cross examination.
      3.   Written Decision:
         a.   If a written or oral response to the proposed disciplinary action
is offered by the employee at the hearing, the human resources director or
mayor's designee shall consider the response and deliver a written decision on
the proposed action to be taken no earlier than forty eight (48) hours and no
later than five (5) working days following the hearing.
         b.   The written notice of final decision must:
            (1)   Include the date of delivery of the notice of final decision.
            (2)   Address the employee's defenses.
            (3)   Identify the specific incidents showing just cause.
            (4)   Cite the violation of rules or mandate.
            (5)   Specify the final decision, including the action to be taken,
or dismissal of charges.
            (6)   Specify the effective date of the suspension and date of
return to work or demotion.
            (7)   Inform the employee that he/she shall have the right to
appeal the disciplinary action under subsection F of this section.
         c.   If no written or oral response to the proposed disciplinary
action is offered by the employee and the employee chooses not to appeal the
disciplinary action, then the proposed disciplinary action will take effect
within a reasonable time after the hearing, as determined by the department
head/supervisor and the human resources director or mayor's designee. A copy of
the disciplinary action shall be placed in the employee's personnel file.
   E.   Termination Hearing:
      1.   Time For Hearing:
         a.   The mayor will schedule and conduct a termination hearing before
the governing body within forty five (45) working days after the pretermination
hearing to terminate an employee. The hearing may be rescheduled within the
stated period by the mayor from time to time, at his sole discretion.
The employee is entitled to:
            (1)   A closed or open hearing.
            (2)   The right to have an attorney at the termination hearing at
the employee's expense.
            (3)   Actual notice of specific charges in sufficient detail to
enable the preparation of a defense.
            (4)   Evidence to be used.
            (5)   The names of adverse witnesses.
            (6)   The opportunity to present his/her own favorable witness
testimony.
            (7)   See the adverse evidence prior to the hearing at least the
day before the hearing.
            (8)   Cross examination of the employee and the employer adverse
witnesses; the rules of evidence shall not apply.
            (9)   Attend the meeting.
         b.   The parties may mutually agree to an alternate time and date for
the hearing to occur either within or without the period provided in subsection
E1a of this section.
      2.   Decision: The governing body will render a decision, in an open
meeting, within a reasonable time after the conclusion of the termination
hearing. Such decision shall be reflected in the minutes of the meeting and a
copy shall be delivered or mailed by certified mail, to the employee. The
employee's right to receive salary or wages and accrued benefits shall cease,
continue, or be amended upon the decision of the governing body. A copy of the
minutes shall be placed in the employee's personnel file. The decision of the
governing body shall be the final step in the administrative process provided
by this section and shall be reviewable in the district court:
         a.   When the decision is arbitrary or capricious; or
         b.   When the decision is unsubstantiated by evidence; or
         c.   When the decision is in excess of the statutory authority or
jurisdiction of the governing body.
      3.   Appeal: Appeal of the decision by the employee shall be taken within
thirty (30) calendar days of the final adverse decision of the governing body
to the district court of Eddy County, New Mexico.
   F.   Demotion, Suspension Hearing:
      1.   Time For Hearing:
         a.   The employee will have two (2) working days after the receipt of
the written notice of final decision within which to take an appeal which must
be made in writing. If the employee appeals the decision to suspend or demote,
the mayor will schedule and conduct a demotion or suspension hearing before the
governing body within forty five (45) working days after the predemotion or
