presuspension hearing to demote or suspend an employee with or without pay. The
hearing may be rescheduled within the stated period by the mayor from time to
time, at his sole discretion.
The employee is entitled to:
            (1)   A closed or open hearing.
            (2)   The right to have an attorney at the demotion or suspension
hearing at the employee's expense.
            (3)   Actual notice of specific charges in sufficient detail to
enable the preparation of a defense.
            (4)   Evidence to be used.
            (5)   The names of adverse witnesses.
            (6)   The opportunity to present his/her own favorable witness
testimony.
            (7)   See the adverse evidence prior to the hearing at least the
day before the hearing.
            (8)   Cross examination of the employee and the employer's adverse
witnesses; the rules of evidence shall not apply.
            (9)   Attend the meeting.
         b.   The parties may mutually agree to an alternate time and date for
the hearing to occur either within or without the period provided in subsection
F1a of this section.
      2.   Decision: The governing body will render a decision, in an open
meeting, within a reasonable time after the conclusion of the demotion or
suspension hearing. Such decision shall be reflected in the minutes of the
meeting and a copy shall be delivered or mailed by certified mail, to the
employee. The employee's right to receive salary or wages and accrued benefits
shall cease, continue, or be amended upon the decision of the governing body. A
copy of the minutes shall be placed in the employee's personnel file. The
decision of the governing body shall be the final step in the administrative
process provided by this chapter and shall be reviewable in the district court:
         a.   When the decision is arbitrary or capricious; or
         b.   When the decision is unsubstantiated by evidence; or
         c.   When the decision is in excess of the statutory authority or
jurisdiction of the governing body.
      3.   Appeal: Appeal of the decision by the employee shall be taken within
thirty (30) calendar days of the final adverse decision of the governing body
to the district court of Eddy County, New Mexico.
   G.   Benefits On Termination:
      1.   All wages, unused annual leave, personal days, floating holiday and
compensatory time will be paid to the employee upon termination, under any
cause. All city property that has been issued to the employee must be returned
and accounted for by the supervisor. The supervisor will notify the payroll
department, by memo, that all equipment has or has not been turned in and any
amounts owed the city for city owned property.
      2.   When employees are laid off, resign, die, or retire, their earned
salary or wages plus any other compensation, such as annual leave and/or
compensatory time accrual, shall be due and payable on the next regular payday.
      3.   When employees are terminated from their position, their earned
salary or wage plus any other compensation, such as annual leave and/or
compensatory time accrual, shall be due and payable within five (5) days of the
effective date of termination, or return of city equipment.
   H.   Death Of Employee: In the event of the death of an employee, all wages
and accrued leave benefits due the employee, up to the time of death, will be
paid to the estate of the deceased. (Ord. 894, 8-27-2012)
1-6-12: PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES:
   A.   Discrimination And Harassment: The city will enforce a
nondiscrimination, harassment and sexual harassment policy to provide employees
with protection against these acts.
   B.   Smoking: Smoking by city employees is prohibited in all publicly owned
buildings and offices. A "publicly owned building or office" means any enclosed
indoor place owned, leased, or rented by the city, excluding any city property
used as a private residence.
   C.   Use Of Drugs And Alcohol While On Duty: Drinking alcoholic beverages or
partaking of alcohol or illegal drugs while on duty, unless a job requirement,
will result in immediate suspension or termination. The city will enforce a
drug and alcohol free policy.
   D.   Possession Of Firearms And Explosives: Possession of a "firearm" and/or
"explosive", as defined by state statute, in the work place while on duty,
unless a job requirement, will result in immediate suspension or termination.
(Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
1-6-13: PERFORMANCE STANDARDS:
The following guidelines have been adopted by the governing body of the city to
preserve public confidence in the integrity of municipal officials and
employees, and to promote high ethical standards in local government service.
These standards are designed to assist city officials and employees in
determining the proper course of action when faced with uncertainty:
   A.   Conflict Of Interest; Gifts Policy:
      1.   No city employee shall accept a favor or gift which would in any way
bring about special consideration, treatment, or advantage to any citizen or
business beyond that which is available to every other citizen or business.
Furthermore, no city employee shall accept any gift or service if it can be
reasonably inferred that the gift was intended to influence him/her in the
performance of his/her official duty or as a reward for any official action.
Any gift with a value of over ten dollars ($10.00) shall be reported to the
employee's supervisor.
      2.   No city employee shall represent the city through the sealed bid or
sealed proposal process in any matter with any firm, corporation, or individual
where an employee stands to benefit because of his/her personal or financial
interest with that firm, corporation or individual without prior consent of the
governing body. No city employee during the period of such employment shall
acquire a financial interest in any new or existing business venture or
business property of any kind when such employee believes or has reason to
believe that the new financial interest may be directly affected by his/her
official act. No city employee shall use confidential information acquired by
virtue of his/her city office or city employment for his/her or another's
private gain.
      3.   Violation of the provisions of this subsection by any city officer
or city employee is grounds for removal or suspension of the officer and
termination, demotion or suspension of the employee.
   B.   Political Activity: City employees shall observe the following with
regard to political activities:
      1.   No city employee shall campaign, distribute literature or solicit
political contributions during his/her scheduled work hours or during any other
employee's scheduled work hours; nor shall campaigning be done while wearing a
city uniform. No city employee shall prohibit the right of another employee to
have and express a personal choice or commitment.
      2.   No employee shall solicit contributions or assessments for any
political party or candidate on city premises. No city employee shall ever be
expected, required or coerced to contribute to any campaign.
      3.   No city employee shall represent or allow himself to be inferred as
representing the city at any political meeting or in political publicity.
      4.   No one shall prohibit any city employee from voting or from
exercising his/her political rights as a private citizen during nonworking
hours.
      5.   A city employee who chooses to run or campaign for political office
and who wishes to campaign during working hours, shall be required to use
annual leave or leave without pay.
      6.   Any city employee involved in projects funded with federal grants in
aid agencies shall be governed by the applicable personnel standards,
regulations and federal laws limiting activities.
      7.   Performance by a city employee of any of the political activities
prohibited in this subsection may be sufficient grounds for disciplinary action
up to and including termination.
   C.   Use Of City Vehicles:
      1.   The following policy will apply to all city employees driving a city
vehicle. City vehicles may be used only:
         a.   In the conduct of city business for travel required while on
duty; or
         b.   Authorized attendance at professional and/or work-related
meetings, classes, seminars and conferences; or
         c.   Travel to and from working assignments beyond normal working
hours.
      2.   Employees who operate city vehicles are required to have a properly
classified and valid New Mexico driver's license in their possession at all
times while operating city vehicles.
      3.   Employees are required to wear installed seat belts while operating
or riding as a passenger in city vehicles.
      4.   Employees who have been assigned cars to take home are permitted
personal use of city vehicles only as it relates to the following: minor retail
shopping in route to and from home, personal appointments with local dentists
or physicians, funeral attendance, and meal breaks.
      5.   Employees who have been assigned cars to take home are assessed a
fringe benefit of the value of the cost, and this benefit will be reflected on
a once a month basis on the payroll, if permitted by law.
      6.   Any city employee violating this policy may be subject to
disciplinary action and/or immediate suspension of driving privilege and
possible termination from city employment.
   D.   Accidents:
      1.   Vehicle Accidents: The following procedures are to be followed in
the event of an accident involving a city vehicle:
         a.   The driver shall immediately notify the nearest police department
and then his/her supervisor of the accident.
         b.   The vehicle should not be moved until the accident has been
investigated by a law enforcement agency. The driver is not to leave the scene
of the accident unless injured and needs medical care. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
      2.   All Accidents: All accidents involving an on-duty city employee must
be reported immediately to the employee's supervisor. If, due to circumstances,
the employee is unable to report to the supervisor immediately, he/she must do
so at the first practical opportunity. All city employees are covered under the
provisions of the New Mexico workers' compensation act 1 . Workers'
compensation claims can be paid only for injuries and illnesses resulting from
on the job accidents. Workers' compensation claims shall be filed in accordance
with New Mexico Statutes Annotated section 52-1-29. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd.
2002 Code)
   E.   Outside Employment: An employee who intends to work for another
employer or engage in an outside business must ensure that such employment does
not conflict with his/her city duties. Outside employment must be reported to
the supervisor and shall not be conducted during duty hours or on city
property. Outside employment shall not in any way impair an employee's
performance while on city duty. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
 
Notes
1 1. NMSA § 52-1-1 et seq.
1-6-14: POSITION CLASSIFICATION PLAN:
   A.   Plan Established: In order to establish fair and impartial methods of
determining salaries, the city has established a position classification plan.
The plan is designed to accomplish two (2) basic results:
      1.   Compare city positions with one another and rank them according to
type of work performed, level of difficulty, responsibility and knowledge,
skills, training and experience required; and
      2.   Arrange a pay plan which provides a logical progression of pay on an
annual basis for each employee. After completion of six (6) month probation of
employment with the City of Artesia employee will be eligible to receive an
annual increase in pay which follows the next step within their current
paygrade under the Compensation Study pay scale. This increase will take effect
annually on July 1 and to be paid starting on the first July pay day schedule.
   B.   Changes: Changes in job positions and/or job descriptions can be
recommended by department heads/supervisors with documentation supporting the
change to the human resources director for review. The human resources director
shall make a recommendation to the mayor of any change needed.
   C.   Hours Of Work: The normal work hours for individuals depends on the
work schedule of the department in which the employee works. Employees should
not work more than their scheduled hours unless they have been requested/
required to do so and/or have permission to do so from their immediate
supervisor.
   D.   Overtime Pay: The city’s workweek for purposes of computing overtime
pay is from twelve o’clock (12:00) A.M. Sunday to eleven fifty-nine o’clock
(11:59) P.M. Saturday. Overtime pay is for hours worked over forty (40) hours
in a week for regular employees, over one hundred six (106) hours in a fourteen
(14) day period for fire department shift personnel and over eighty (80) hours
worked in a 14-day period for police department shift personnel.
   E.   Deductions From Pay:
      1.   The city is required by federal and state laws to make payroll
deductions for income tax purposes. These deductions are carried under the “pay
as you go” plan on the basis of the number of dependents declared by the
employee on form W-4.
      2.   Deductions may include: social security (FICA), medicare, federal
income tax and state income tax. Other deductions such as retirement, credit
union payments, health and life insurance may be made. Additional deductions
may be made, if required by an official order of the court.
   F.   Health Insurance: The city requires all employees to be covered under
the city’s health insurance, unless proof of insurance through another source
is provided. Dependent coverage is optional for the employee. Employees are
required to be covered by the city’s disability insurance. Disability premiums
are employee funded.
   G.   Retirement: There are two (2) city funded retirement programs.
Participation is mandatory and employees are eligible after hire date for
coverage. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd. 2002 Code; Ord. 941, 7-8-2014; Ord. 1001,
8-23-2016; Ord. 1101, 8-9-2022; Ord. O-1133, 7-23-2024)
1-6-15: EXEMPT OR NONEXEMPT STATUS:
Exempt or nonexempt status classification is determined by each position’s
requirements and responsibilities as measured by the specific formula
established by the fair labor standards act.
   A.   Nonexempt Employees: Nonexempt employees, excluding fire and police
shift personnel, will be employed for a workweek of forty (40) hours. Nonexempt
employees will receive compensation for any authorized work in excess of forty
(40) hours worked weekly at a rate of not less than one and one-half (1 ½)
times the regular hourly rate at which the employee is employed. Fire shift
personnel are scheduled to work on shift work, and are paid overtime when the
hours worked exceed one hundred six (106) in a fourteen (14) day period. Police
department shift personnel are paid overtime when the hours worked exceed
eighty (80) in a fourteen (14) day period. If requested by the employee and
approved by their supervisor or department head, compensatory time will be
given freely and without coercion or pressure in lieu of overtime pay.
   B.   Exempt Employees:
      1.   Supervisors and others exempt from the overtime requirements of the
fair labor standards act as “executive”, “administrative”, or “professional”
employees are considered by the city to be paid for work done rather than the
time spent doing it. It is city policy that such exempt employees, except those
in the department of public safety, shall not, in any case, receive additional
pay for working longer hours than the standard for nonexempt employees.
      2.   Exempt employees of the department of public safety who work special
projects may receive additional compensation for those special projects.
      3.   The governing body will adopt, by resolution, the approved list of
special projects and the rates to be paid.
   C.   Volunteer Time: Volunteering time to the benefit of the city is not
permitted.
   D.   Travel And Training: With permission from the governing body, full time
or part time employees will be granted time off with pay to attend schools,
seminars or training programs if attendance is at the request of and for the
benefit of the city. This will include payment for books, tuition, mileage and
all approved out of pocket expenses. Any personal education attendance not
required by the city will be on the employee’s own time and at his/her own
expense. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd. Ord. 647, 3-12-2002; Ord. 1001, 8-23-2016)
1-6-16: LEAVE POLICY:
   A.   Holidays: The city will recognize paid holidays as established by
resolution.
   B.   Annual Leave:
      1.   A regular or probationary full-time employee will accrue annual
leave on the last day of the month. An employee must complete one (1) full
calendar month of employment after initial appointment before annual leave
begins to accrue.
      2.   Annual leave accrual rates for 2,080 hours per year employees are as
follows:
 
1-59 months of service    6.66 hours per month or 80 hours per year
60-119 months of service  10 hours per month or 120 hours per year
120-248 months of service 13.33 per month or 160 hours per year
249+ months of service    16.66 hours per month or 200 hours per year
 
      3.   Annual leave accrual rates for 2,756 hours per year employees are as
follows:
 
1-59 months of service    10 hours per month or 120 hours per year
60-119 months of service  14 hours per month or 168 hours per year
120-248 months of service 20 hours per month or 240 hours per year
249+ months of service    24 hours per month or 288 hours per year
 
      4.   An employee who is serving initial probation will accrue annual
leave during probation but shall not use such leave until satisfactory
completion of initial probation of six (6) months.
      5.   A regular or probationary part-time employee will accrue annual
leave on a prorated basis calculated on average hours worked per month. An
employee must complete one (1) full calendar month of employment after the
initial appointment before annual leave begins to accrue.
      6.   An employee, other than a Fire Department shift employee, may carry
over a maximum of 240 hours of annual leave at the end of the calendar year any
hours over 240 hours will be forfeited.
      7.   A fire Department shift employee may carry over a maximum of 360
hours of annual leave at the end of the calendar year any hours over 360 hours
will be forfeited.
      8.   Annual Leave-Temporary Employees: A temporary employee does not
accrue annual leave.
      9.   Annual Leave-Deductions: Annual leave will be deducted hour per hour
as taken.
      10.   Annual Leave-Long-Term Leave With Pay: An employee who is on leave
with pay for over six (6) consecutive months shall not accrue annual leave for
longer than six (6) months.
      11.   Annual Leave-Duty Disability: An employee who is on duty disability
leave for over thirty (30) consecutive calendar days shall not accrue annual
leave during the time off nor shall the time off be creditable service for
leave accrual rate purposes beginning with the first day off on duty disability
leave.
      12.   Annual Leave-Leave Without Pay: An employee who is on leave without
pay for over thirty (30) consecutive calendar days shall not accrue annual
leave during the time off nor shall the time off be creditable service for
leave accrual rate purposes beginning with the first day off on duty disability
leave
      13.   Annual Leave-Military Leave: An employee who is on military leave
and is reinstated shall not accrue annual leave for the period of military
leave
      14.   Annual Leave-Layoff: An employee who is laid off and is reinstated
shall not accrue annual leave for the period of layoff.
      15.   Annual Leave-Termination:
         a.   A regular employee who terminates shall be paid for unused
accrued annual leave.
         b.   A probationary employee who terminates shall not be paid for
unused accrued annual leave.
      16.   Annual Leave-Exhaustion of Accrued Time: An employee who has used
all their accrued annual leave, and sick leave is not applicable, shall be
placed on leave without pay. The employee shall be subject to all rules
pertaining to leave without pay.
   C.   Sick Leave:
      1.   General Provisions:
         a.   Sick leave may be granted for absence from duty because of
personal illness, illness in the immediate family (child, stepchild, spouse,
maternal or paternal parent, or any individual for whom the employee is a legal
guardian), injuries or legal quarantine; provided, that the employee has sick
leave accumulated. If sick leave is used to stay home and care for an illness
in the immediate family and the employee needs more than three (3) days or
should intermittent absences become excessive, department heads or supervisors
may, upon written notice to the employee, require leave to be taken in
accordance with the family and medical leave act. “Personal illness” is defined
to include scheduled doctor’s appointments for health examination, evaluation
and/or treatment.
         b.   Doctor’s appointments may require documentation.
         c.   Hours worked in addition to the regularly scheduled workweek will
not entitle the employee to additional sick leave benefits.
         d.   Part time employees will receive prorated benefits.
         e.   When an employee becomes ill while on annual leave, sick leave
may be substituted for annual leave upon presentation of a physician’s written
statement.
      2.   Certification Of Sick Leave:
         a.   Employees absent from work, when such absence is charged to sick
leave, may be required to provide their supervisor with a doctor’s statement,
using a city form, certifying that the absence from work was due to illness or
legal quarantine.
         b.   Any employee taking sick leave shall, upon returning to work,
sign a certificate stating the reason for such leave. The employee claiming
sick leave shall cooperate with persons designated by the mayor to make
investigations concerning claimed sick leave.
         (1) All probationary and regular full time employees will accrue one
day of sick leave for each month of continuous employment. Fire department
shift personnel accrue twelve (12) hours per month sick leave.
         (2) An employee can accumulate up to a maximum of one hundred twenty
(120) days’ sick leave, or nine hundred sixty (960) hours; fire department
shift personnel maximum accrual is sixty (60) 24-hour shifts or one thousand
four hundred forty (1,440) hours.
         (3) Salary paid during sick leave shall be based on the regular work
schedule of an eight (8) hour day, forty (40) hour workweek; sick leave for
fire department shift employees shall be based on their regular salary for such
employee’s shift work.
         (4) Accumulated sick leave shall not be taken as annual paid leave.
All sick leave is to be approved and authorized by the employee’s immediate
supervisor. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
      3.   Abuse Of Sick Leave:
         a.   An employee who abuses sick leave by using it for purposes other
than sickness, nonduty disability, medical treatment, hospitalization, doctors’
appointments, or not in accordance with subsections C1 and C2 of this section,
will have the absence charged as leave without pay and will be subject to
disciplinary action, including possible termination. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd.
2002 Code)
         b.   Employees suspected of making false claims and failing to
cooperate in any investigation by the city of their claim for sick leave, or
sign a certificate containing a false statement, shall not be entitled to any
leave with pay for the time in dispute. Such actions are considered just cause
for disciplinary action up to and including termination.
   D.   Personal Business Days: Employees may elect to take two (2) personal
business days per year, to be deducted from the accrued sick leave. Personal
business days are to be approved and authorized by the employee’s immediate
supervisor.
   E.   Family And Medical Leave: The purpose of this subsection and subsection
F of this section is to comply with the family and medical leave act (FMLA),
and the provisions herein should be construed in accordance with the provisions
of that act and the regulations adopted pursuant to that act.
      1.   General Provisions:
         a.   Regular full time employees with one or more years of service
and/or who have worked one thousand two hundred fifty (1,250) hours within the
twelve (12) month period as a rolling three hundred sixty five (365) day period
preceding their request may take up to twelve (12) weeks’ leave without pay
(LWOP), or any combination of annual leave, sick leave, or LWOP totaling twelve
(12) weeks for:
         (1) The birth of the employee’s son or daughter, and care for the
child.
         (2) The adoption or foster care placement of a child by the employee.
         (3) The employee’s care for a spouse, parent, or child (if the child
is under 18 or is incapable of self care because of a physical or mental
disability) when they have a “serious health condition”.
         (4) The employee’s recovery from or treatment for a “serious health
condition” making the employee unable to perform his/her job functions.
      Employees requesting leave under this act must use up to twelve (12)
weeks of their accumulated sick and/or annual leave, depending on the category
of leave taken before being placed on leave without pay status. (Ord. 615, 6-
13-2000)
      Once an employee is placed on LWOP status under this act, he/she must pay
his/her portion of the health insurance premium. Payment may be made in cash on
an every other week basis. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd. 2002 Code)
         b.   “Serious health condition” is defined to include any illness,
injury, impairment, physical, or mental condition involving in patient care at
a hospital or other medical facility or continuing treatment by a healthcare
provider; “healthcare provider” is defined as any doctor of medicine or
osteopathy who is authorized to practice medicine or surgery by the state in
which the doctor practices.
         c.   Parental leave in categories E1a(1) or E1a(2) of this section may
only be taken during the child’s first twelve (12) months with the employee.
         d.   Parental leave in categories E1a(1) or E1a(2) of this section may
not be taken intermittently (e.g., September and December) or on a reduced
leave schedule (e.g., 4 hours per workday, 30 hours per workweek, etc.) unless
the department head and employee so agree.
         e.   Employees taking medically necessary intermittent or reduced
scheduled leaves may be required to transfer temporarily to an alternate
position for which the employee is qualified, which has equivalent pay and
benefits, and which better accommodates recurring periods of leave than does
the employee’s regular position.
         f.   Intermittent and/or reduced schedule leaves will be provided when
the leave is taken because of a serious health condition (categories E1a(3) and
E1a(4) of this section), and the intermittent or reduced schedule leave is
certified by a healthcare provider as “medically necessary”.
         g.   It is possible that an eligible employee could claim entitlement
annually over a number of years so long as each leave was one of the four (4)
categories stated above.
         h.   In the event a city employee is eligible to take leave under
category E1a(1), E1a(2) or E1a(3) of this section and is a spouse of another
city employee eligible to take leave under category E1a(1), (2) or (3) of this
section, the two (2) spouses are entitled to take up to twelve (12) weeks of
leave each in any twelve (12) month period.
         i.   An employee taking leave due to categories E1a(3) and E1a(4) of
this section may be required to provide a certification of the condition from a
treating healthcare provider. If the city has reason to doubt the validity of
the certification provided for herein, the city may also require, at its own
expense, a second opinion from a healthcare practitioner designated or approved
by the city; provided, however, that such second healthcare provider may not be
employed on a regular basis by the city. In cases where the two (2) opinions
conflict, a third opinion shall be obtained by a healthcare provider designated
or approved jointly by the city and employee. The third opinion shall be
binding upon both the city and the employee.
         j.   In the case of any leave taken under the act, the city has the
right to require the employee to weekly inform his/her supervisor of the
expected remaining duration of the leave. Therefore, employees will contact
their supervisor weekly by telephone and monthly in writing as to their
expected duration of leave.
         k.   Employees taking leave under the provisions of the family and
medical leave act, upon their return to work, will be restored to their
previous position or to another equivalent position with equivalent employment
benefits, pay, and other terms and conditions of employment. However, employees
who have taken LWOP for reasons other than those covered by the family and
medical leave act may be reinstated only if a vacant position exists for which
the individual is qualified.
      2.   Scheduling Leave Under Family And Medical Leave Act:
         a.   The act places a modest burden on the employee who wishes to take
one of the leaves in categories E1a(1) through E1a(4) of this section to give
the city notice of the intended departure date.
         b.   An employee wishing to take parental leave in categories E1a(1)
and E1a(2) of this section must give the city at least thirty (30) days’ notice
of the intended departure date. An exception is made for situations where the
birth or placement of the child precludes the thirty (30) day notice. In such
cases, the employee must provide as much notice as is practicable.
         c.   Employees wishing to take a serious health condition leave in
categories E1a(3) and E1a(4) of this section must, where the leave is based on
a foreseeable, planned medical treatment, make a reasonable effort to schedule
the treatment so as to not unduly disrupt city operations, and must provide at
least thirty (30) days’ notice before the leave is to begin. An exception may
be made where the date of the treatment requires less notice.
   F.   Maternity/Paternity Leave:
      1.   Employees who anticipate using maternity/paternity leave shall
mutually agree with their supervisor for an estimated date when leave will
begin and an estimated date of return.
      2.   A female employee may use any combination of sick leave and annual
leave for the entire maternity leave period. After all leave with pay is
exhausted, the employee must be placed on the inactive payroll until the
balance of her twelve (12) weeks of family and medical leave has been
exhausted, or a negotiated return date (if greater than 12 weeks) has expired,
she has returned to duty, or has terminated her employment.
      3.   When a child is adopted or placed in foster care, male and/or female
employees must use all accrued annual leave before being placed on LWOP status
during the father/mother/child familiarization period. That period of time may
not exceed twelve (12) weeks under the family and medical leave act. Time may
be extended under a negotiated leave agreement. If both spouses work for the
city, they are entitled to take twelve (12) weeks of family and medical leave
each, although the FMLA only requires spouses to take up to twelve (12) weeks
between them.
      4.   A male employee may request paternity leave in order to care for his
family during the wife’s pregnancy and/or postpartum recovery period. Depending
on the circumstances, paternity leave may be charged to annual leave, sick
leave, or leave without pay for a total of twelve (12) weeks. Time may be
extended under a negotiated leave agreement. If both spouses work for the city,
they are entitled to take twelve (12) weeks of leave each.
      5.   An employee who uses maternity or paternity leave will be guaranteed
an equivalent position, providing the employee returns to work within the
twelve (12) weeks covered under the family and medical leave act. In the event
of medical complications or other conditions which may preclude returning to
work within twelve (12) weeks, the employee will communicate with his/her
supervisor and must agree on another date of return. It must be understood that
the employee cannot be guaranteed an equivalent position indefinitely.
      6.   In the case of any leave taken in excess of eighty (80) hours, the
city has the right to require the employee to weekly inform his/her supervisor
of the expected remaining duration of the leave. Therefore, employees will
contact their supervisor weekly by telephone and monthly in writing, as to
their expected duration of leave. Failure to notify their supervisor
accordingly may result in termination unless other arrangements have been
agreed to.
      7.   Prior to maternity/paternity leave, supervisors should contact the
human resources department to make arrangements for a temporary replacement. If
no city employee may be transferred, the supervisor must secure authorization
for a temporary hire from the city according to standard personnel request
practice.
      8.   The city may require a medical certificate for FMLA leave and may
require a certificate of fitness upon return to work.
   G.   Military Duty Leave: All city employees who are members of organized
units of the army or air force national guard or army, air force, navy, marine
or coast guard reserves shall be given not to exceed fifteen (15) working days’
military leave with pay per federal fiscal year when they are ordered to duty
for training, such leave to be in addition to other leave or vacation time with
pay to which such employees are otherwise entitled in compliance with New
Mexico Statutes Annotated section 20-4-7. The employee must provide a copy of
his/her orders to report for duty to his/her department head/supervisor in
order for this to be paid and tracked by the payroll department.
   H.   Jury Duty: Employees will be granted time off with pay to attend jury
duty. In the event jury duty is for less than a day, the employee shall
immediately return to work. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
   I.   Funeral Leave: A maximum of three (3) working days with pay will be
allowed to any employee for attendance of a funeral upon the death of a member
of that employee’s family. “Family” is defined as the spouse, child, stepchild,
parent, brother, sister, grandparent or grandchild of the employee or the
employee’s spouse or any individual for whom the employee is a legal guardian.
An additional day may be granted for every five hundred (500) miles traveled
one way from Artesia, required to attend funeral services. Proof of death may
be required before the absence may be charged to funeral leave. (Ord. 970, 6-9-
2015)
   J.   On The Job Injury Leave: Injuries that occur on the job for the city
are paid through a workers’ compensation program. On the job injury payments
for the first week of disability shall be paid by the city. If the employee
returns to work before being paid for the first week by workers’ compensation,
no reimbursement is necessary. If the employee is paid for the first week of
absence by workers’ compensation, the city is reimbursed for the first week’s
compensation. An employee shall elect, in writing, to receive workers’
compensation benefits for weekly pay benefits or take sick leave or annual
leave accrual.
   K.   Leave Without Pay: Time off, without pay, may be granted for a period
not to exceed one year. Such leave of absence without pay must be in the city’s
best interest and with the approval of the governing body of the city. An
employee who has taken leave without pay for reasons other than those covered
by the family and medical leave act may be reinstated only if a vacant position
exists for which the individual is qualified. An employee must exhaust all
annual leave before beginning leave without pay. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000; amd.
Ord. O-1112, 6-27-2023)
1-6-17: DEPARTMENT RULES:
Each department may have established additional rules to aid in the department
efficiency, approved by the mayor, and not in conflict with any ordinance of
the city. Sanctions for violating department rules and regulations are subject
to disciplinary policies stated in this chapter. (Ord. 615, 6-13-2000)
1-6-18: PERSONNEL RECORDS:
The city maintains a file of each employee's official personnel data. These
files are public record, except as identified by the inspection of public
records act 1  and/or federal law. An employee has the right to inspect and
request the correction of inaccurate information in his/her personnel file. It
is the employee's responsibility to assure that the file has current personal
information, including changes in name, address, phone number, beneficiary
(ies), and certificates of additional training or schooling. (Ord. 615, 6-13-
2000)
 
Notes
1 1. NMSA § 14-2-4 et seq.
CHAPTER 7
COLLECTIVE BARGAINING
SECTION:
1-7-1: Short Title
1-7-2: Purpose And Interpretation
