Silver     0.10
 
(1996 Code § 13.16.050)
      2.   If any wastewaters are discharged or are proposed to be discharged
to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the
characteristics enumerated in subsection C1 of this section and which, in the
judgment of the governing body of the city, may have a deleterious effect upon
the wastewater facilities or receiving waters or which otherwise create a
hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the governing body of the city
may:
         a.   Reject the wastes;
         b.   Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to
the public sewers; or
         c.   Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge.
If the governing body of the city permits the pretreatment or equalization of
waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be
subject to the review and approval of the governing body of the city and the
state, and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances and
laws. (1996 Code § 13.16.060)
 
Notes
1 1. This article derived from ordinance 415, passed in 1979.
7-3A-4: GREASE INTERCEPTOR FACILITIES:
   A.    Description: The purpose of an interior or exterior grease interceptor
is to remove grease or oil from the sewage prior to discharge to the public
sanitary sewer. These interceptors serve as small flotation chambers where
grease rises to the water surface and is retained, while the clearer water
underneath is discharged. As used in this section, the word "interceptor" is
interchangeable with the word "trap".
   B.    Regulatory Guideline: No water or waste containing substances as
defined in subsection 7-3A-3C of this article shall be discharged into any
public sanitary sewer.
   C.    Special Requirements: The size and type of grease interceptor shall be
subject to the prior approval of the city's building inspector. The grease
interceptor shall be installed in a plumbing line separate from the sanitary
plumbing facilities. In general, all grease interceptors shall be designed for
exterior installation and be of capacity sufficient to service those grease
generating fixtures connected thereto. Wastes other than those requiring
separation shall not be discharged into the grease interceptor. Grease
interceptors shall be designed, located and constructed in a manner that will
permit easy access and maintenance by the user and for inspection by the city.
   D.    Grease Interceptor Standards: The minimum requirements for interceptor
sizing, construction, materials and other features shall be those required by
the uniform plumbing code (UPC), latest edition, together with any
modifications, revisions or amendments which may be made by the state of New
Mexico and/or the city building inspector.
   E.    Grease Interceptor Requirements:
      1.   Grease interceptors existing upon the adoption of this chapter shall
not be exempt from the provisions in this section.
      2.   All restaurants, cafeterias, institutional kitchens, and other
installations having facilities for the preparation and serving of food in
quantity, laundromats, car washes, gas stations, auto machinery garages and art
shops or art galleries where the potential for discharge of grease, oils and
waxes into the sanitary sewer system exists, whose location is within the
city's sanitary sewer service area shall be required to install a grease
interceptor.
      3.   Any facility as listed above that is currently operating without the
required grease interceptor, even though there may have been no history of
blockages caused at or downstream from their location, shall be required to
install a grease interceptor.
      4.   Owner shall submit plans or technical drawings for installation of a
grease interceptor as required by this section within three (3) months
following receipt of any notice of noncompliance.
      5.   Owner shall then have up to six (6) additional months from date of
approval of the drawings by the city building inspector within which to install
the grease interceptor.
      6.   An application for new water or sewer service connection may be
denied pending the installation of a grease interceptor.
      7.   Any commercial or industrial facility, currently on an on site sewer
system and making an application to connect to the public sanitary sewer, shall
install or otherwise show proof of the existence of a grease interceptor
installed in compliance with this section, prior to approval of the
application.
      8.   Any commercial or industrial facility which is not in compliance
with this section and is connected to the public sanitary sewer system shall be
required to be in compliance with these rules and regulations on or before the
date of any sale of the premises to a new owner and prior to the new owner
being allowed to commence discharge. In the event of any failure to bring such
premises into compliance on the date of sale, the city may elect to refuse to
accept any discharge into the system until such facility be brought into
compliance.
   F.    Maintenance: Grease interceptors shall be cleaned prior to the
receptacle achieving a total content of seventy five percent (75%) of its
design capacity. The operator of a grease interceptor shall maintain a log book
showing date and description of all maintenance activities together with a log
book containing entries indicating the name and address for each person making
disposal of grease or oil, which shall be readily available for immediate
inspection upon request by the city. Grease interceptors shall additionally be
subject to unannounced inspections by the city's wastewater department,
building inspector or code enforcement officer, or any other lawful
representative of the city at any time during their operation.
   G.    Penalty; Publication: The penalties designated within section
7-3A-9 of this article shall apply. In addition, the city may publish in a
newspaper published within the city the name of any person or entity who may be
determined by judgment of the municipal court to be in violation of this
section. (Ord. 798, 7-8-2008)
7-3A-5: PRELIMINARY TREATMENT:
Where preliminary treatment or flow equalizing facilities are provided for any
industrial wastewater, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory
and effective operation by the owner at his expense. (1996 Code § 13.16.090)
7-3A-6: CONTROL MANHOLE AND METERS:
The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial
wastewater shall install a suitable control manhole, together with such meters
and other appurtenances on the building sewer to facilitate observation,
sampling and measurement of the wastewater. Water use records shall be kept by
the owner and shall be made available to the governing body of the city. Such
manhole, meters and other appurtenances shall be accessible and safely located,
constructed in such a manner as to prevent infiltration of ground and surface
waters, and should be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the
governing body of the city. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his
expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all
times. (1996 Code § 13.16.100)
7-3A-7: MEASUREMENTS, TESTS AND ANALYSES:
   A.    Testing of industrial wastewater will be performed at least twice a
year or whenever found necessary by the governing body of the city. The persons
discharging the wastewater shall be liable for payment of all costs arising
from the testing of the industrial wastewater. (1996 Code § 13.16.070)
   B.    All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters
and wastewaters shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of
"Standard Methods For The Examination Of Water And Wastewater", published
jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works
Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation and shall be determined
at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at the control
manhole. The control manhole shall be located so that sampling of the
industrial waste will be performed before discharge into the public sewer
system.
   C.    Sampling shall be carried out in accordance with present or future
state or federal standard methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon
the wastewater facilities and to determine the existence of hazards to life,
limb and property. The particular analyses involved will determine whether a
twenty four (24) hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or
whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always,
COD, BOD, suspended solids and settleable solids analyses are obtained from
twenty four (24) hour composites of all outfalls, whereas pHs are determined
from periodic grab samples. (1996 Code § 13.16.110)
7-3A-8: RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.    Rate Schedule Established: The governing body of the city shall take
necessary steps to establish a rate schedule for sewer service that assures an
equitable system of user charge and cost. The intent of this schedule is that
all users shall pay for the costs incurred by the governing body of the city in
the construction, operation and maintenance of this wastewater facility. (1996
Code § 13.16.120)
   B.    User Charge System:
      1.   Conditions: The user charge system shall satisfy the following
conditions:
         a.   The apportionment of costs must take into consideration each
user's contribution as related to the total waste load, taking into account the
volume and strength of all discharges. The volume shall be determined by either
winter water usage or by number of outlets per user. The method for determining
volume to be used will be reviewed annually concerning its equitability as to
each user's contribution.
         b.   The user charge to be considered should include, but not be
limited to:
            (1)   Amortization of the applicant's indebtedness for the cost of
the treatment facilities (plant and interceptors).
            (2)   Operation and maintenance of the treatment facilities.
            (3)   Any additional costs which are necessary to assure adequate
treatment on a continuous basis.
         c.   The user charge system shall be evaluated on an annual basis to
reflect annual costs. (1996 Code § 13.16.130)
      2.   Formula: A user charge will be assessed against persons discharging
industrial wastewater based on volume and strength. The industrial user charge
will be calculated with a formula acceptable to the governing body of the city,
as shown on the forms entitled appendix A attached to ordinance 415 which is on
file in the office of the city clerk. The governing body of the city or its
designated employee shall insert cost figures in the appropriate blanks of
appendix A attached to ordinance 415 as soon as such cost figures are
available. (1996 Code § 13.16.140)
   C.    Additional Charges:
      1.   In addition to the user charge referred to in subsection B2 of this
section, each industrial user shall pay that portion of the public law 92-500
federal grant amount allocable to the treatment of its industrial wastewater.
An "industrial user" is defined in section
7-3A-2 of this article.
      2.   A signed letter of intent from each industrial user is required in
order for the user to discharge into the wastewater facilities. No discharge
will be permitted if the industrial wastewater has significant impact on the
wastewater facilities. The industrial cost recovery charge will be calculated
with a formula acceptable to the governing body of the city, as set out in
appendix A of ordinance 415 which is on file in the office of the city clerk.
      3.   Each year during the industrial cost recovery period, each
industrial user of the wastewater facilities shall pay its share of the total
federal grant amount divided by the "recovery period" which is defined as the
useful life of the wastewater treatment works or thirty (30) years, whichever
is less.
      4.   If there is a substantial change in the strength, volume or delivery
flow rate characteristics introduced into the treatment works by an industrial
user, such user's share shall be adjusted accordingly. (1996 Code § 13.16.150)
7-3A-9: PENALTIES:
   A.    General Penalty: Every person convicted of a violation of this article
shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per
day and/or imprisonment of up to ninety (90) days in jail for each violation,
and each day this article is violated shall constitute a separate offense
against the municipality. The conviction and punishment of any person for a
violation of this article shall not excuse or exempt such person from the
payment to the municipality of any separate fee, civil or otherwise, which may
be due, owing, or unpaid at the time of such conviction.
   B.    Other Remedies: All remedies prescribed or liens created hereunder or
under the provisions of the law for collection and enforcement of the fees
shall be cumulative to any other remedies provided within this article or by
law and the use of one or more remedies by the city shall not bar the use of
any other remedy for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this article or
any liens created by the law. The fees fixed by this article shall be a lien in
favor of the city upon both the real and personal property of the person used
in connection with the sewer line or facilities which gave rise to the fee, and
such lien shall be imposed, collected, enforced and paid as provided by the
law. (Ord. 798, 7-8-2008)

7-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their
derivatives shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the
context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the
singular include the plural, and words used in gender text are not descriptive.
The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory.
ASHES: The residue from burning of wood, coal, coke, or other combustible
materials.
AUTHORIZED CONTRACTOR: Any solid waste hauler who has been contracted by the
city to provide solid waste hauling services.
BULKY WASTE: Used and discarded mattresses, furniture, white goods
(appliances), and other waste materials other than construction debris, dead
animals, prohibited materials, infectious or hazardous waste.
CITY: The city of Artesia, New Mexico.
CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: The employee of the city who enforces designated
portions of this code.
COLLECTION CONTAINERS: City approved receptacles, bins, roll- offs, roll-out
carts, or other containers authorized by the city and utilized by generators of
solid waste and/or recyclables for temporary storage during the process of
collection, disposal, or recycling.
COMMERCIAL COLLECTION: Solid waste collected from any source other than from
residential accounts.
COMMERCIAL HAULER: Anyone that collects or transports solid waste as a part of
his business or for a fee, to include handymen and landscapers, and/or anyone
who transports solid waste by use of a vehicle defined as commercial by the
state or the federal government (i.e., requiring a commercial driver's
license).
CONSTRUCTION AND DEMOLITION DEBRIS: Materials such as dirt, rocks/stones,
concrete, masonry, bricks, mortar, asphalt, shingles, wood, etc. Residential
customers producing or hauling construction debris in quantities larger than
three (3) cubic yards, and commercial producers or haulers of construction
debris in any quantity shall be defined as a "commercial customer" and the
designated fees shall be charged for use of the city's transfer station.
DEPARTMENT: The department of infrastructure.
DIRECTOR OF INFRASTRUCTURE: The employee of the city designated to be
responsible for the administration and compliance of this chapter.
DOMESTIC/RESIDENTIAL USER: Any person who uses city collection services or
designated transfer station to dispose of household waste.
GARBAGE: Putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling,
preparation, cooking, and consumption of food.
HAZARDOUS WASTES: Solid waste that is deemed as hazardous under federal
statutes, rules or regulations.
INFECTIOUS WASTE: A limited class of substances that carry a risk of
transmitting disease, including, but not limited to:
   A.   Microbiological laboratory wastes, including clinical and stocks of
infectious agents from clinical research and industrial laboratories, and
disposable culture dishes and devices used to transfer, inoculate and mix
cultures;
   B.   Pathological wastes, including human or animal tissues, organs and body
parts, removed during surgery, autopsy, or biopsy;
   C.   Disposable equipment, gloves, instruments, utensils, and other
disposable materials which require special precautions because of contamination
by highly contagious diseases;
   D.   Blood and blood products, including waste blood, blood serum and
plasma;
   E.   Used gloves, sharps, including used hypodermic needles, syringes,
scalpel, blades, Pasteur pipettes, and broken glass; and contaminated animal
carcasses, body parts and bedding, especially those intentionally exposed to
pathogens in research, in the production of biological or the in vivo testing
of pharmaceuticals.
LANDFILL: A New Mexico environment department (NMED) permitted landfill.
MOBILE HOME PARK: Any plot of ground upon which three (3) or more mobile homes,
occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes, are located regardless of whether
or not a charge is made for such accommodation.
PERSON/RESPONSIBLE PARTY: Any individual, firm, partnership, corporation,
cooperative, association, or any other entity owning, operating, managing,
leasing, controlling, or inhabiting any house, unit of residence, shop,
establishment, or other premises within the corporate boundaries of the city.
PREMISES: Any property within the city corporate boundaries adaptable for human
occupancy, and shall also mean, but not be limited to, business places,
apartment houses, offices, theaters, hotels, residences, cafes, restaurants,
eating places, tourist facilities, hospitals, schools, vacant lots, and any
other places or locations within the city boundaries where solid waste
accumulates.
PROHIBITED MATERIALS: Any and all materials listed as prohibited by NMED, city,
state, or federal rules, regulations, or law.
QUALIFIED PHYSICALLY DISABLED RESIDENT: As determined by a physician, means a
residential account where there are no residents who are physically capable of
moving a residential container (roll-out) to and from the standard curbside
location for collection.
RESIDENTIAL COLLECTION: Solid waste collected from premises occupied as
individual residential dwellings, containing no more than four (4) families per
lot, and mobile home park where the water and/or sewage service is furnished by
the city and billed to the individual occupant of the mobile home.
RUBBISH: Shall include, but is not limited to, all nonputrescible solid wastes
(excluding ashes), such as paper, cardboard, cans, wood, yard clippings,
leaves, dirt, glass, bedding, crockery, and similar materials.
SOLID WASTE: Any discarded garbage, rubbish, refuse, sludge from a waste
treatment plant, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution control
facility and other discarded material including solid, liquid, semisolid or
contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, commercial, mining and
agricultural operations and from community activities, but does not include
those items excluded as solid waste by the solid waste rules adopted by the
environmental improvement board of the state of New Mexico.
SOLID WASTE SUPERVISOR: The supervisor responsible for day to day operations
for the solid waste department, to include the implementation of policy and
procedures as instructed by the director of infrastructure.
SPECIAL WASTES: Types of solid wastes that have unique handling,
transportation, or disposal requirements to assure protection of the
environment and the public health and safety as defined by New Mexico solid
waste rules.
TRANSFER STATION: A facility designated by the city as a disposal site for
solid waste.
YARD WASTE: Grass clippings and/or leaves. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-2: ADMINISTRATION:
   A.   Duties Of The Director Of Infrastructure: The director of
infrastructure is responsible for the administration and enforcement of this
chapter utilizing the solid waste supervisor and the code enforcement officer.
It shall be the duty of the director of infrastructure to oversee the handling
and collection of all solid waste in the city and disposal or processing
thereof. He shall have the authority to adopt rules and regulations to
implement this chapter.
   B.   Service Conversions: All service conversions from a current collection
system to an alternate service (i.e., roll-out containers to shared containers
or shared containers to roll-out containers), shall be recommended by the solid
waste supervisor. Should the conversion be approved by the infrastructure
director, reasonable notice will be given to the affected customers.
   C.   Size, Location, Quantity And Type Of Service Needed: The solid waste
supervisor, under the direction of the director of infrastructure, is
responsible for evaluating the size, type of collection container, location,
quantity, and type of service or equipment necessary to provide the required
services to residential and commercial accounts. In cases of disputes or
complaints arising from such decisions, the department shall designate the
size, location, quantity, and type of service needed for said containers,
taking into consideration among other things, convenience to collection crews,
convenience to customers, safety of residents and employees, and if hazardous
conditions exist (i.e., electrical wires, etc.).
   D.   Duties Of The Solid Waste Supervisor: The solid waste supervisor shall:
      1.   Monitor residential and commercial compliance as outlined in this
chapter.
      2.   Oversee bid or contract work as applicable to the solid waste
department.
      3.   Monitor and follow departmental rules and regulations, and meet all
city, state, and environmental requirements.
      4.   Hear and decide complaints brought by a person concerning another
person's compliance with the terms of this chapter.
      5.   Notify persons whose collection containers are not in conformity
with the requirements in this chapter.
      6.   Approve the locations of, and need for, all containers.
      7.   Notify persons if unsanitary conditions exist.
      8.   Resolve disputes regarding placements of solid waste collection
containers.
      9.   Order additional residential and commercial pick ups or collection
containers, at the responsible party's expense, if unsanitary conditions exist.
   E.   Grievance Procedure: Any person aggrieved by a decision of the solid
waste supervisor may appeal first to the director of infrastructure. If the
matter is not resolved, then to the infrastructure committee. A final appeal
can be brought before the full city council.
   F.   Designation Of Enforcement Authority: The solid waste supervisor may
issue notice for lack of compliance or violation of this chapter, and/or the
solid waste rules and regulations. Any city police officer, building inspector,
code enforcement officer, fire marshal, or any other city employee authorized
by the governing body, is authorized to issue citations for any violation of
this chapter, and proceed with enforcement. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-3: COLLECTION OF SOLID WASTE, CONTRACTS:
   A.   The city shall provide for suitable equipment and personnel sufficient
to collect solid waste within the city. This may be provided internally or by
contract. To achieve such purposes, the governing body may enter into contract
for the collection, transportation, facilities, or disposal of solid waste.
   B.   Collection companies providing services not yet offered by the city
may, by authorization of the department, contract with persons for the
placement and removal of roll-off containers for the purpose of hauling
construction debris or large quantities of solid waste, provided all rules and
regulations for the temporary storage, collection, transportation, and control
of solid waste are followed. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-4: COLLECTION AUTHORIZATION:
   A.   Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, solid waste accumulated
in the city shall be collected, conveyed, and disposed of by the city or its
contractors. No person other than the city, a commercial hauler, or an
authorized contractor shall collect, transport or dispose of any solid waste
accumulated in the city. Except that the actual producer of solid waste, or
responsible party for the property where solid waste has accumulated, may
personally collect and transport such solid waste providing it is done in a
sanitary manner, which will prevent any waste from spilling, blowing, or in any
other manner being deposited on any public or private property. Said person
shall deposit such solid waste in an authorized landfill site or transfer
station.
   B.   Notwithstanding the terms of this section, all persons shall arrange
for residential or commercial solid waste collection with the city, and shall
pay for such service, whether or not the city services are actually used. (Ord.
880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-5: ACCUMULATION OF SOLID WASTE:
   A.   No person shall allow any solid waste to accumulate upon premises or
real property owned, leased, or occupied by him during intervals between
collection thereof, except in the manner provided by this chapter.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to deposit any solid waste in or upon the streets,
alleys, sidewalks, gutters, rights of way, or vacant land within the city,
except in the assigned containers as hereinafter specified.
   C.   No person shall allow any material or solid waste to accumulate in or
around the circumference of a fire hydrant. A minimum of twenty feet (20') of
clear space from the fire hydrant must be maintained at all times.
   D.   Should accumulation of solid waste become a nuisance, create a fire
hazard, or should it appear to be a matter of public necessity for health or
safety reasons, or should such accumulation be otherwise violative of this
chapter, the responsible party of the premises shall be notified in person, by
notice posted upon the premises, or by regular first class mail. The notice
shall describe the violation and shall establish a reasonable time limit for
abatement thereof by the person/responsible party, at his own expense.
Compliance shall be within fifteen (15) days after the date of notice, except
in cases where hazardous materials are involved, in which case the compliance
period shall be shortened to forty eight (48) hours.
   E.   In the event the responsible party does not respond to the notice of
violation, or compliance, the city will proceed with enforcement and abatement
as described in this chapter. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-6: RESIDENTIAL COLLECTION:
   A.   Residential Container Required; Maintenance Required: Every person or
responsible party within the city boundaries shall cause to be provided, on his
premises, one or more of the solid waste collection containers in sufficient
number to contain all solid waste accumulated by said person between
collections. Such containers shall meet the following specifications and be
maintained as required:
      1.   Containers shall be provided by the city without exception.
      2.   Containers supplied by the city shall remain the property of and
responsibility of the city.
      3.   Containers shall be maintained in mechanically sound condition by
the city.
      4.   The city shall be entitled to seek restitution from the responsible
party assigned the collection container for all maintenance, repairs, or loss
occasioned by the negligent or intentional acts of the person or third parties
from which damage has occurred.
      5.   The combined weight of the collection containers and contents shall
not exceed one hundred fifty (150) pounds for roll-out carts and one thousand
eight hundred (1,800) pounds for large three (3) yard containers.
   B.   Residential Collection Regulations: All collection containers shall be
loaded with bagged solid waste only and in such a manner as they will self-
empty when inverted. Yard waste is exempt from the bagging requirement.
      1.   Solid waste that is too long or "bulky" to be placed in the
collection containers as required by this chapter, shall be prepared for
collection by compressing the rubbish as flat as practicable, or by breaking or
cutting items into shorter lengths, and securely tying them in a bundle not
exceeding four feet (4') in length and fifty (50) pounds in weight. No solid
waste such as light packing materials, or other similar and easily scattered
materials shall be included in the bundle, nor shall any solid waste or
material not defined as rubbish. Such bundles and bulky waste shall be placed
as instructed by the city.
      2.   The owner, occupant, tenant, or lessee of each premises shall store
the containers in such a manner as to keep the containers from being overturned
or upset and scattered in any manner.
      3.   The solid waste supervisor shall notify and advise any person out of
compliance with this chapter, in writing by ordinary first class mail or by
posting on the premises, and order corrective action as appropriate. If the
issue is not corrected within fifteen (15) days of the date of mailing of the
notice or posting on the premises, the person shall be deemed in violation of
this chapter, and enforcement action may be taken.
   C.   Residential Collection Times, Locations And Frequency:
      1.   The department will determine scheduled pick up days and times,
placement locations, and types of collection containers based on routing, safe
access, staffing, and equipment available. All residential roll-out containers,
other than at a qualified physically disabled residence, shall be placed out
for pick up no later than seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. on the regularly scheduled
day, but no earlier than seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. the evening prior to pick up
unless otherwise authorized by the department.
      2.   Roll-out containers shall be placed as close to the front curb as
possible, wheels shall be touching or within six inches (6") of the curb. It
shall be placed so the opening faces the street assigned for pick up, without
causing interference with pedestrians, vehicular traffic, or fire hydrants.
      3.   Containers shall be clearly visible and accessible to collection
equipment and employees, and free from any obstructions including, but not
limited to, trees, shrubbery, walls, fences, and vehicles. All emptied
containers shall be removed from the curb area within twelve (12) hours of
collection.
      4.   Qualified physically disabled residents will contact the solid waste
supervisor for a physician approved application. The solid waste supervisor
will establish pick up procedures for their current circumstance. (Ord. 880,
11-8-2011)
7-4-7: COMMERCIAL COLLECTION:
   A.   Commercial Container Required; Maintenance Required: Such containers
shall meet the following specifications and be maintained in the specified
manner:
      1.   Commercial or business establishments and multiple-family dwellings
with more than four (4) dwellings on a single site are required to have a
commercial container unless each individual unit establishes a single
residential account.
      2.   It is the responsibility of the city to arrange for commercial
containers, which are compatible with the city's solid waste collection
equipment.
      3.   The size and specifications of a commercial collection container
shall be based on the volume and type of solid waste produced by the particular
business, or commercial account establishment, or multiple-family dwelling. In
cases of disputes or disagreements concerning the appropriate size or
quantities of collection containers, the department may order a change in the
size of the container or frequency of collections.
      4.   The city shall collect all solid waste which is contained inside the
approved commercial collection container to be serviced for that premises. The
solid waste shall not exceed the collection container's capacity and the
container's lid must be closed when not in use. The person shall not place any
solid waste in any area other than inside the solid waste collection container.
      5.   The city shall maintain, repair, or repaint a container as needed.
The city shall be entitled to seek restitution for all maintenance, repairs, or
loss occasioned by the negligent or intentional acts of the person or third
parties from which damage or loss occurred.
      6.   All collection containers shall be loaded with bagged solid waste
only and in such a manner as they will self-empty when inverted.
      7.   All solid waste collection containers shall be kept in a clean,
sanitary condition by the user. It shall be a violation of this chapter to
deposit used grease from any commercial account holder established to produce
food products. Grease from such shall be deposited into a grease dumpster. It
shall be the responsibility of the account holder to prevent such activity.
      8.   Should the responsible party wish to temporarily or permanently
relocate a collection container, or make a change in service he may request a
review from the solid waste supervisor. It is the responsibility of the owner
of the premises to notify the department of any change in business type.
   B.   Criterion For The Placement Of Commercial Collection Containers:
      1.   Container shall at all times be located in such a manner as to be
readily accessible for removing and emptying. Criteria for placement shall
include consideration of accessibility to the container, and the safety to
residents, equipment and employees.
      2.   No commercial container shall be placed on any premises, street, or
alley without prior approval of the department.
      3.   A person, property owner, or his agent, whose site will require
commercial collection, shall submit to the department an accurate site plan of
the whole site for which service is desired. The plan shall include a legal
description and shall show lot lines, existing and planned buildings, proposed
collection points and enclosures (including the design of the enclosure), and
the proposed location of each commercial container.
      4.   The specific location for a commercial container shall be approved
by the department. Commercial containers and enclosure facilities shall be
located according to the criteria approved by the department.
      5.   The department may require alternative locations, enclosures, or
designs as necessary.
   C.   Commercial Collection Times, Container Size And Frequency:
      1.   Commercial Collection Times: Commercial containers shall be serviced
between the hours of four o'clock (4:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. on
the regularly scheduled pick up days.
      2.   Commercial Collection Frequency: It shall be the responsibility of
the city and the commercial user to determine the quantity, cubic yard size,
and number of pick ups per week for commercial containers. The minimum number
of pick ups shall be one time per week. If, in the opinion of the solid waste
supervisor, unsanitary or unsafe premises are being maintained, he shall notify
the responsible party of this fact either in person, by notice posted upon the
premises, or by regular first class mail. If within fifteen (15) days of the
date of mailing or posting of the notice the premises are not brought into
compliance, the person shall be in violation of this chapter.
      3.   Shared Commercial Containers: For commercial business that do not
warrant three (3) yard containers or larger, and when so determined by the
department, commercial users may be allowed to share three (3) yard containers
and the fees for such. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-8: GENERAL RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL COLLECTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   Bagging: All collection containers shall be loaded with bagged solid
waste only and in such a manner as they will self-empty when inverted. Yard
waste is exempt from the bagging requirement.
   B.   Burning: It shall be unlawful to burn any material inside any
collection container, or otherwise place smoldering or burning items into or
next to any city collection container.
   C.   Construction Debris Containment: All construction sites shall have a
method of containment for construction debris to prevent the debris from
blowing or scattering upon the site or adjacent properties and streets. The
method of containment shall meet with the approval of the department.
   D.   Construction Debris Collection: Construction debris and/or materials
(herein "construction debris") in quantities larger than three (3) cubic yards,
or which may be produced or collected by a commercial business or hauler shall
be also considered as commercial or construction debris, and fees for such
shall apply. Producers of construction debris shall arrange for the collection
and removal of such at his own expense. If the city provides this service, said
person shall contract with the city, except that the producer may personally
collect said construction debris and transport it to the designated transfer
station. Transportation shall be in a vehicle, and shall be both covered and
secured in such manner to prevent the construction debris from spilling,
blowing, or in any other manner from being deposited on any street, roadway, or
property.
   E.   Flammable Or Explosive Materials: It shall be unlawful to place
flammable or explosive materials in any residential or commercial containers.
The producers of such materials shall provide a method of disposal which meets
with current New Mexico state solid waste rules.
   F.   Hot Ashes And Other Combustible Material: It shall be unlawful to
deposit into any city container hot ashes, cinders, smoldering coals, or any
greasy or oily substances which may spontaneously combust.
   G.   Infectious Waste: It shall be unlawful to place in any container for
regular collection any infectious waste or an item that has come in contact
with infectious waste.
   H.   Special And Hazardous Waste: It shall be unlawful to place or cause to
be placed in any container for collection any special or hazardous waste of any
kind. Any special or hazardous waste shall be removed from the city at the
owner's or producer's expense to an approved site. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-9: HOLIDAYS:
The city shall observe holidays as noncollection days as approved annually by
the city's governing body. Residential collection shall occur on an alternate
day approved by the department. Commercial collections during such holidays
shall be performed on the day either prior or after the holiday. (Ord. 880, 11-
8-2011)
7-4-10: UTILITY RATES AND FEES:
   A.   Fees: The governing body may from time to time, by resolution, set fees
for the use of the transfer station, monthly collection services, and special
services offered by the solid waste department. Charges will be levied each
month for all utilities offered and any special services requested for the
collection and disposal of solid waste, in addition to other city utilities,
whether or not the solid waste collection service is actually used. Failure to
comply is a violation of this chapter.
   B.   Notice To Stop Services: Continuation of charges set forth by this
chapter shall continue until the responsible party or owner of such premises
provides notice in writing to the municipal clerk requesting such services be
stopped, and after all city issued collection containers have been returned to
the solid waste department.
      1.   Vacant premises shall continue to incur charges until all city
issued collection containers have been returned to the solid waste department,
and the city documents the vacancy through contact with the tenant or the
owner.
      2.   Accounts where a collection container has been assigned by the city
shall continue to incur monthly fees until the issued collection containers
have been returned to and received by the city's solid waste department or the
replacement costs for such container are collected.
      3.   Any person making a false statement upon any application or request
to stop services pursuant to this chapter shall be in violation of this
chapter.
   C.   Rendition Of Bills: The city shall bill persons, responsible parties,
firms, corporations, or other legal entities subject to this chapter for all
fees and associated costs to said persons residential or commercial account on
a monthly billing schedule established by the municipal clerk. Such bills may
include, but are not limited to, charges for commercial dumping, use of
transfer station, loss or damage to collection containers, special services,
water service, sewer service, and garbage collection, and shall be payable upon
receipt whether or not the service is actually used. All said bills shall be
payable at the office of the municipal clerk or billing office.
   D.   Past Due Bills: Residential and commercial utility accounts, commercial
dumping accounts, and any other account established with the city that remains
unpaid for over ninety (90) days from the billing date shall be processed for
collection by any lawful means; and/or in the event a property be connected for
said services and no payment be timely received, then the city may have any
recourse against the responsible party or property as provided by law,
including, but not limited to, filing a lien against the property for said
unpaid indebtedness. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-11: COMPULSORY COLLECTION, RESPONSIBLE PARTY:
Any person or responsible party of any real property or premises within the
city upon which solid waste is generated or accumulated shall make arrangements
with the city for the collection of solid waste. Such persons shall pay to the
city the fees established and set forth from time to time by resolution of the
city council, whether or not the solid waste collection service is actually
used. Failure to comply is a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-12: NO WITHHOLDING OF PAYMENT OF ANY ACCOUNT HOLDER:
No persons shall withhold payments owed to the city for services furnished
under this chapter for any reason to include before, during, or after a
customer feels aggrieved by the city. Upon failure to pay appropriate
statements or to bring current the delinquent account the city may thereupon
pursue its legal remedies under applicable laws. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-13: FAILURE TO PLACE IN PROPER COLLECTION CONTAINERS; FAILURE TO USE CITY
AUTHORIZED COLLECTION SERVICE; FAILURE TO PAY FEES:
The city may remove or order the removal of any solid waste from any real
property or any premises, if:
   A.   Any person or responsible party of a property or premises allows solid
waste to be deposited or accumulated upon said property other than in the
proper collection container and fails to remove solid waste or to place the
solid waste in the proper collection container.
   B.   The person or responsible party for any real property or premises
refuses to use the solid waste collection service provided by the department.
Such persons shall pay to the city the fees established in this chapter,
whether or not the solid waste collection service is actually used. Failure to
comply is a violation.
   C.   After such removal of solid waste the city shall bill said person the
charge allowed under this chapter for any required removal. The city may file a
lien against the premises if the charges not be paid in full within thirty (30)
days after billing date. Failure to pay such charge is a violation of this
chapter. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-14: UNAUTHORIZED USE OF COLLECTION CONTAINERS:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the person/responsible party to remove solid
waste from any rights of way within the city. It shall be unlawful for any
person to place, or permit another to place, any solid waste inside any
collection container at any collection point used in the city for collection
service, unless the solid waste is from the premises served by the collection
container or from the premises at which the container or collection point is
located.
   B.   City collection containers are placed at several points in city areas
to provide for solid waste collection from residential and commercial areas,
i.e., apartments, businesses, parks, and institutions within the city
boundaries for use of city customers only.
No solid waste from outside the city boundaries shall be placed in any city
collection containers or on the ground at such locations.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to place or deposit, or permit
another to place or deposit, prohibited or hazardous solid waste into or next
to any city serviced collection containers.
   D.   The responsible party for any building, house, structure or land shall
cause to be removed, at his own expense, all hazardous and prohibited solid
wastes which are located, owned, or deposited on the property or on or within
the public right of way adjacent to the property within forty eight (48) hours
of notice from the solid waste supervisor or code enforcement officer. Notice
of the fact may be made in person, posted on the premises, or sent by first
class mail. The existence of any hazardous or prohibited materials on the
property or within the adjacent public right of way after notice has been given
and the required time has expired, shall be prima facie evidence that such
person, owner or occupant has failed or refused to remove the item or items so
stored or located thereon and shall be held to answer for the violation.
   E.   No person shall deposit or otherwise place in any collection container
to be serviced by the city or its contractor, any carcass, offal, or portion of
any animal, bird or reptile, including blood of the same. Any person in the
city having knowledge of the existence and location of a dead animal, bird or
reptile shall immediately notify the animal control officer of the location of
such dead animal, bird or reptile and shall provide such information as the
animal control officer or agent designated by the city may require.
   F.   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter to deposit any
solid waste on the public streets, alleys, or public ways except in proper
collection containers; or to deposit such waste on vacant lots or outside of
collection containers with the intent to avoid proper collection, or payment
for services under the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-15: SUPERVISION OF COLLECTION CONTAINERS, NOTICE TO THE DEPARTMENT OF
FAILURE TO EMPTY COLLECTION CONTAINERS:
Each person, owner, manager, occupant, tenant or lessee of a house or building
used for residential, business or commercial purposes shall maintain
supervision and surveillance over the solid waste and the collection containers
serving such premises. If such collection containers are not emptied and the
contents removed by an employee of the city or other duly authorized person,
said person shall notify the department of the fact. (Ord. 880, 11-8-2011)
7-4-16: ENFORCEMENT; COMPLIANCE; VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
   A.   Any city police officer, building inspector/code enforcement officer,
agent, fire marshal, or any other authorized person, may issue a notice that a
citation will be issued for any violation of this chapter. The notice shall be
directed to the owner or responsible party of the property on which the
violation occurs. Said notice may be issued in person, by notice posted upon
the premises, or by regular first class mail. After such notice is issued,
correction or abatement of said violation shall be done within forty eight (48)
hours from the time of issuance of the notice, at the owner or responsible
person's sole expense. In the event of failure to correct or abate said
violation within forty eight (48) hours from the issuance of the notice, a
citation or complaint against the offender shall be issued for the violation.
Additionally, failure to comply with the correction or abatement of said
violation shall be deemed to be an additional separate offense for each day for
which such violation continues.
   B.   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of a petty misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to
penalty as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this code.
   C.   In addition, the city may seek restitution from the owner or
responsible party for the costs of all cleanup, removal, abatement, or
remediation for any solid, hazardous, or prohibited wastes billed the city. The
owner or responsible party for said property will be billed the actual costs
for the cleanup, removal, abatement, or remediation by the city, plus a one
hundred dollar ($100.00) administration fee. If the amount owed remains unpaid
after thirty (30) days after the billing date, a finance charge equal to one
percent (1%) per month commencing thirty (30) days after invoice date shall be
charged by the city until the account be paid in full, and the city shall have
all legal remedies for collection of the amounts owed.
   D.   The city shall additionally have lien rights against a particular
property for all amounts which may be owed and unpaid to the city. (Ord. 880,
11-8-2011)
CHAPTER 5
WATER WASTE
SECTION:
7-5-1: Title And Purpose
7-5-2: Definitions
7-5-3: Watering Restrictions
7-5-4: Water Conservation Incentives
7-5-5: Violation, Enforcement, And Fines
7-5-6: Variances, Exemptions And Administrative Appeals
7-5-7: Severability Clause
7-5-1: TITLE AND PURPOSE:
This chapter shall be known as the WATER WASTE AND DEMAND MANAGEMENT ORDINANCE.
The purpose of this chapter is to:
   A.   Assist in reducing overall per capita water use by twenty five percent
(25%) by improving the management of water demand.
   B.   Reduce outdoor irrigation and irrigation related water waste, which
comprise over forty percent (40%) of the total annual water use.
   C.   Reduce peak summer usage, which can be two (2) to three (3) times
winter usage and is a major driver for capital, operations and maintenance
investment.
   D.   Reduce water waste, including: ineffective, inefficient or over
watering; and release of water resulting in fugitive water in the public right
of way.
   E.   Reduce damage to publicly owned streets and appurtenances, and the
public expenditures necessary to repair and maintain such damages.
   F.   Increase roadway safety by reducing the potential of standing, flowing
or frozen water in the public right of way.
   G.   Reduce the rate of capital, operation, maintenance and replacement
investment needed to adequately meet system demand and consequently reduce the
cost to water consumers. (Ord. 966, 4-28-2015)
7-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter, the following words or phrases shall be defined as:
CITY SERVICE AREA: That area that is served by the city both within the city
limits and within Eddy County.
CITY WATER: Shall include all water supplied or intended to be supplied through
the city of Artesia municipal water system for use. The term shall not include
effluent water or water obtained from either a private well or from private
irrigation water rights.
COMMERCIAL WATER USER: A business that uses city water for the purpose of
domestic use, in quantities that reflect such. This definition includes
companies using city water on construction sites for the purpose of dust
control.
DOMESTIC PURPOSES: The use of water for household or other domestic use.
FUGITIVE WATER: The pumping, flow, release, escape, or leakage of any water
from any pipe, valve, faucet, connection, diversion, well, or any facility for
the purposes of water supply, irrigation, transport, storage, disposal,
recreational use, cleaning process or deliver onto adjacent property or the
public right of way.
HAND WATERING: Watering plants or crops with one handheld hose, fitted with a
self-canceling or automatic shutoff nozzle, or a water can or pail.
INDUSTRIAL WATER USER: Any water user, in the city's sole and final
determination, which has used or does use city water for any nondomestic
purposes including, but not limited to, the following uses:
   A.   Oil field servicing and oil and gas production.
   B.   Manufacturing and production industries.
   C.   Any other industrial usage other than domestic use.
PERSON: Any individual, entity, partnership, association, agency, corporation,
or business organization of any kind, whether profit and not for profit, or any
other organization or entity of any kind, whether profit or nonprofit, except
for a municipal corporation.
PRIVATE WELL: Any water well for which a valid permit and diversion right has
been granted to any person by the office of the New Mexico state engineer.
SPRAY IRRIGATION: Shall include any irrigation by permanent sprinkler
installation and hose connected portable sprinkler devices.
SWIMMING POOL: Shall include any structure that is twenty four (24) or more
inches in depth and capable of containing at least one thousand one hundred
twenty two (1,122) gallons of water and which is intended primarily for
recreational or for exercise purposes. The term shall not include indoor pools
used for medical or rehabilitative purposes.
TREATED EFFLUENT: Those waters the city recovers through its sanitary sewer
system and treats at the city of Artesia wastewater treatment plant facility
for irrigation purposes, for discharge into the Pecos River, or for other
permissible and appropriate purposes.
WASH A VEHICLE: Includes the washing of any type vehicle by an individual or
individuals including, but not limited to, the operation of vehicle washes as a
fundraiser, subject to the limitations contained in the definition of "treated
effluent" herein and section
7-5-3 of this chapter. It does not include the washing of vehicles when that
activity is conducted either by attendants, with automatic equipment, or by
self-service, and is done as part of a normal business operation on the
premises of a commercial car wash or a commercial service station, provided
that such business holds a current business license from the city.
WATER WASTE: The nonbeneficial use of city water.
   A.   Nonbeneficial uses of city water include, but are not restricted to:
      1.   Applying water to outdoor vegetation in such a manner, rate, or
quantity that it overflows the area being watered and runs onto or seeps into
adjacent property or any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public right of way.
      2.   Using a sprinkler, sprinkler system, or other outdoor vegetation
water application device in such a manner as to spray water onto adjacent
property or any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public right of way; or
      3.   Washing down of vehicles or hard surfaces such as parking lots,
sidewalks, driveways, pads, or aprons when water is applied without a shutoff
hose nozzle and in an excessive amount or quantity of water such that it flows
from that surface onto adjacent property or any street, alley, sidewalk, or
other public right of way.
      4.   Water applied in sufficient quantity to cause ponding on impervious
surfaces or ice formation on adjacent property or the public right of way.
   B.   "Water waste" shall not include:
      1.   The use of water for firefighting, or firefighting training, or the
inspection or testing of fire hydrants.
      2.   The appropriate use of water to abate spills of flammable or
otherwise hazardous materials.
      3.   The use of water to prevent or abate health, safety, or accident
hazards when alternative methods are not available.
      4.   The use of water as a dust control measure as may be required by
regulations or work practice.
      5.   Water flow resulting from the construction, inspection, operation,
or maintenance of the city of Artesia municipal water supply system.
      6.   The use of water by contractors or utilities in saw cutting of
pavement, for compaction, or for other use required under the terms of their
construction contracts; or
      7.   Water which reaches or flows onto adjacent property or public right
of way when caused by an emergency, vandalism, or an act of God. (Ord. 966, 4-
28-2015)
7-5-3: WATERING RESTRICTIONS:
The following restrictions apply to all customers within the city service area:
   A.   No person shall cause or permit water waste of city water.
   B.   Self-canceling or automatic shutoff nozzles are required on any hoses
used for hand watering, car washing or other outdoor use.
   C.   All spray irrigation during the period beginning on April 1 and ending
on October 31 of each calendar year must occur only between seven o'clock (7:
00) P.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. This restriction shall not apply to
drip irrigation and low head bubblers, hand watering, or watering of
containerized plants and plant stock.
   D.   Plants which cannot be kept alive without daily watering may be watered
from a container, but shall not be watered through a sprinkler, sprinkler
system, hose or any other source on the days or during the times when watering
is otherwise prohibited.
   E.   Restaurants and food service facilities shall provide drinking water to
customers only upon request.
   F.   Any leak in a system which carries, transports, delivers, or stores
city water must be repaired within five (5) working days after first discovery
of the leak.
   G.   The city may require and enforce the elements of the most recently
adopted or amended emergency response and drought management plan.
   H.   The city may require that customers water no more than one, two (2) or
three (3) time(s) per week.
   I.   The city may prohibit curbside car washing. (Ord. 966, 4-28-2015)
7-5-4: WATER CONSERVATION INCENTIVES:
   A.   The city may, at its sole discretion, implement a water conservation
incentive program.
   B.   The mayor or his/her designee is delegated authority to implement the
provisions of a water conservation incentive program.
   C.   A water conservation incentive program may include:
      1.   Conversion to low water use (xeric) landscaping.
      2.   Replacement of indoor plumbing fixtures to low flow.
      3.   Installation of an indoor hot water recirculation system.
      4.   Installation of rainfall sensors with automatic sprinkler irrigation
systems.
      5.   Incentives and rebates.
   D.   If implemented, incentives and rebates will be through the utility
bills for the responsible party's billing account. (Ord. 966, 4-28-2015)
7-5-5: VIOLATION, ENFORCEMENT, AND FINES:
   A.   Any officer of the Artesia police department and/or any employee of the
city of Artesia engaged in code enforcement duties is authorized to enforce
this chapter.
   B.   All violations of this chapter shall be subject to and within the
jurisdiction of the municipal court of the city of Artesia.
   C.   Upon conviction for a violation of this chapter, the schedule for
imposition of fines by the court upon conviction for violations of this chapter
is as follows:
      1.   First violation: Twenty five dollars ($25.00).
      2.   Second violation: Seventy five dollars ($75.00).
      3.   Third violation: Three hundred dollars ($300.00).
      4.   Fourth and any subsequent violation: Five hundred dollars ($500.00).
No fine imposed for violation of this chapter may be suspended or deferred by
the court.
   D.   With respect to violations of this chapter that are continuous with
respect to time, each day the violation occurs shall constitute a separate
offense.
   E.   In addition to or in lieu of such fine, the person's access to city
water may be administratively terminated or otherwise restricted by the city of
Artesia. (Ord. 966, 4-28-2015)
7-5-6: VARIANCES, EXEMPTIONS AND ADMINISTRATIVE APPEALS:
The mayor may prescribe policies, rules, or regulations to carry out the intent
and purposes of this chapter. Any variance or exemptions from this chapter
shall be addressed to the mayor or upon appointment by the mayor for such
purpose, the designee of the mayor.
   A.   Variances Or Exemptions: Variances or exemptions to section
7-5-3, "Watering Restrictions", of this chapter or the definition of "water
waste" in section
7-5-2 of this chapter:
      1.   Administrative variances or exemptions to the restrictions in this
chapter may be issued by the mayor or his/her designee, only for the purposes
of installing or retrofitting landscaping, provided that the general intent of
this chapter has been met, compliance with this chapter is proven to cause
practical difficulties and unnecessary hardship, and all options for abatement
through modified water management have been exhausted. The criteria to
determine hardship shall include level of capital outlay required and time
required to be in compliance with this chapter.
      2.   Water waste variances may be issued for a period not to exceed one
year and shall stipulate both short term corrective measures and a schedule for
completion of long term corrective measures. Variances may be renewed on an
annual basis if long term corrective measures cannot in the exercise of due
diligence, reasonably be completed within one year.
      3.   Watering restriction variances may be issued for a period not to
exceed one hundred twenty (120) days to establish a turf area on properly
prepared barren ground.
      4.   Watering restriction exemptions may be issued for a period not to
exceed forty five (45) days to establish a newly sodded turf and/or landscape.
      5.   Watering restriction exemptions may be issued for a period not to
exceed forty five (45) days to establish inter-seeded areas within an
established turf area.
   B.   Administrative Appeals: Appeal of administrative actions by mayor or
designee of section
7-5-3, "Watering Restrictions", of this chapter or the definition of "water
waste" in section
7-5-2 of this chapter.
   C.   Judicial Review: The exclusive remedy for parties dissatisfied with the
actions of the mayor or his/her designee taken under section
7-5-3, "Watering Restrictions", of this chapter or the definition of "water
waste" in section
7-5-2 of this chapter shall be by filing an appeal of the administrative action
taken by the mayor or his designee to the district court of Eddy County and
shall be limited to the record of any administrative hearing held pursuant to
this section. Such appeal shall be taken by the appellant by filing an appeal
with the district court of Eddy County and service of a copy of the appeal upon
the city clerk of Artesia within fifteen (15) days following final action taken
by the mayor or his/her designee pursuant to this section. (Ord. 966, 4-28-
2015)
7-5-7: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
The provisions of this chapter are severable, and if any provision or
circumstance is held invalid or unenforceable, then such invalidity or
unenforceability shall not affect any other provision or application of this
chapter which can be given effect without the invalid or unenforceable
provision or application. (Ord. 966, 4-28-2015)

of a fire hydrant. This includes temporary barricades, fences, or gates.

Section 105.7.13 - Fire Hydrants. A construction permit is required for the

not require a permit.

Artesia.

Section 105.7.19 - Means Of Egress. A construction permit is required for any
new construction involving a means of egress, alteration to any existing means

Exceptions: Any work limited to replacement of the existing door or door
hardware with the same type/rating of door and hardware.
Section 105.7.20 shall be added:
Section 105.7.20 - Demolitions. A permit is required for the demolition of any
structure, including but not limited to, buildings, fire department access
roads, bridges, or towers.

in all hearings.

EASEMENT- The right, liberty, advantage or privilege that one (1) individual or
entity has in lands of another, either express or imputed (utility, grant or
necessity).

8-1-12: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
   A.   Violation Of Codes: It shall be unlawful and a violation of this title
for any person, firm, corporation or other entity to erect, construct, enlarge,
alter, repair, move, improve, convert or demolish, or to equip, use, occupy or
maintain any building or structure or building service equipment in the City of
Artesia, or to cause or permit the same to be done, contrary to or in violation
of any of the provisions of this title.
   B.   Actions For Violation: Any building official, Code Enforcement Officer,
or other designated enforcement employee of the City of Artesia may, for any
violation of this title, take any one or more of the following actions:
      1.   Stop inspections, and/or revoke any or all permits issued to the
owner or contractor for the project until each such violation be corrected.
      2.   Impose double the usual amount of permit fee(s) if work be commenced
without first having a valid issued permit.
      3.   Impose a reinspection fee for any repeat inspection performed after
any violation is corrected.
      4.   Refuse to authorize installation of gas, electric, water service, or
other utility service until the violation be corrected.
      5.   Cause gas, electric or water service to be removed from the premises
until the violation be corrected.
      6.   Cause a certificate of occupancy to not be issued or, if issued, to
be withdrawn.
      7.   Issue a Municipal citation as provided in title 1, chapter 4 of this
Code.
Any violation of this title shall be considered a separate offense for each and
every day which such violation is committed, continued, permitted, or otherwise
not corrected. (Ord. 911, 2-12-2013)
TITLE 9
ZONING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL ZONING PROVISIONS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Short Title
9-1-2: Purpose
9-1-3: Interpretation; Compliance With Provisions
9-1-4: Buildings And Lots
9-1-5: Multiple Use; Reduction Of Lot Areas
9-1-6: Sight Triangle Requirements
9-1-7: Driveway Location Requirements
9-1-8: Building Placement And Stormwater Requirements
9-1-1: SHORT TITLE:
This title is cited as and referred to as the ZONING ORDINANCE or the ZONING
ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF ARTESIA. (Ord. 1028, 8-28-2018)
9-1-2: PURPOSE:
This title is enacted for the purpose of promoting the health, safety, morals,
convenience, orderly prosperity and welfare of the present and future
inhabitants of the City by lessening of congestion in the streets and roads;
securing safety from fire and other danger; providing adequate light and air;
the classification of land uses and the distribution of land development and
utilization; avoiding undue congestion of population; facilitating the adequate
provision of transportation, water, schools, sewerage and other public
requirements; and by other means in accordance with the comprehensive plan, and
the zoning map adopted herewith. (Ord. 1028, 8-28-2018)
9-1-3: INTERPRETATION; COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
   A.   Interpretation: In interpreting and applying the provisions of this
title, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of
the public safety, health, convenience, comfort, morals, prosperity and general
welfare. It is not intended by this title to interfere with or abrogate or
annul any easements, covenants or other agreements between parties; except,
that if this title imposes a greater restriction, this title shall control.
   B.   Compliance Required: The use of premises and all buildings in the City
shall be in accordance with the minimum standards established in this title.
(Ord. 1028, 8-28-2018)
9-1-4: BUILDINGS AND LOTS:
Every building shall be on a lot, and accessory buildings shall not be placed
on a lot without a main building occupying the same lot. (Ord. 1028, 8-28-2018)
9-1-5: MULTIPLE USE; REDUCTION OF LOT AREAS:
Yards, number of parking spaces or lot area required for one main building
cannot be used for another main building, nor can the size of a lot be reduced
below the requirements of this title unless a variance is approved in
accordance with the provisions of chapter 13 of this title. (Ord. 1028, 8-28-
2018)
9-1-6: SIGHT TRIANGLE REQUIREMENTS:
In all districts, and except as cited below, no obstruction to view in excess
of three feet (3') in height, including, but not limited to, buildings/
structures, driveways and parking spaces (where a parked vehicle or vehicles
would be a visual obstruction), fences/walls, landscaping and associated design
features (berms, boulders, decorative lighting, statues, etc.) and signs, shall
be placed in the following areas:
   A.   On any corner lot/parcel within a triangle formed by street property
lines and a line connecting them at points twenty feet (20') from the
intersection of the street property lines.
   B.   On any lot/parcel within a triangle formed by a newly platted alley
line and a street property line and a line connecting them at points ten feet
(10') from the intersection of the newly platted alley line and street property
line.
   C.   On any lot/parcel within a triangle formed by a driveway line and
street property line and a line connecting them at points ten feet (10') from
the intersection of the driveway line and street property line, on both sides
of the driveway.
Street light poles, traffic control signal poles, traffic regulating signs and
utility poles (but not utility boxes or pedestals) that exceed three feet (3')
in height may be located in the sight triangle areas if they are placed in a
manner that permits unobstructed vision to pedestrians and vehicle drivers.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/8c85ba56d28ea2897d39ed92e67a92923b877ac2/
IMAGES/0-0-0-1319.gif]
(Ord. 1028, 8-28-2018)
9-1-7: DRIVEWAY LOCATION REQUIREMENTS:
In all districts, the location of driveways on a lot/parcel shall be placed in
a manner that provides safe ingress and egress, taking into account both
vertical sight distance (determining visual obstructions extending vertically
from property and adjoining street right-of-way grades) and horizontal sight
distance (determining visual obstructions due to changes in street grade
elevations). A driveway shall not be placed within twenty feet (20') of an
intersection of street property lines unless a variance is approved in
accordance with the provisions of chapter 13 of this title. (Ord. 1028, 8-28-
2018)
9-1-8: BUILDING PLACEMENT AND STORMWATER REQUIREMENTS:
In all districts, and regardless of whether there are no setback requirements
in some districts, and regardless of any setback encroachment allowances, the
following building placement and stormwater requirements shall apply:
   A.   The roof of a building shall not project across a property line.
   B.   Stormwater runoff from the building shall not run onto an adjacent
property.
   C.   No building shall be placed over any drainage or utility easement.
   D.   All other provisions of this title and applicable Building and Fire
Codes regarding buildings shall be adhered to. (Ord. 1028, 8-28-2018)
CHAPTER 2
RULES AND DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
9-2-1: Rules Of Word Construction
9-2-2: Definitions
9-2-1: RULES OF WORD CONSTRUCTION:
As used in this title, the words and phrases set out in this chapter shall be
interpreted and defined in accordance with the provisions set forth in this
chapter. Any words not listed among the definitions in this chapter shall be
defined by Webster's Dictionary for their common usage.
   A.   The particular controls the general.
   B.   In case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of
this title and the captions for each section, the text shall control.
   C.   The words "will" and "shall" are always mandatory and not directory.
The word "may" is permissive.
   D.   Words used in the present tense include the future, unless the context
clearly indicates the contrary.
   E.   Words used in the singular number include the plural, and words used in
the plural number include the singular, unless the context clearly indicates
the contrary.
   F.   A "building" or "structure" includes any part thereof. A "building" or
"other structure" includes all other structures of every kind, regardless of
similarity of buildings. (Ord. 1029, 8-28-2018)
9-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
ACCESSORY BUILDING/     A subordinate building/structure, that is not a portion of the main building/
STRUCTURE:              structure, the use of which is incidental to that of the main building/structure
                        on the same lot/parcel, except as otherwise provided in this title.
ACCESSORY USE:          A use which:
                       A.   Is subordinate to and serves the principal building/structure or principal
                        use;
                       B.   Is subordinate in area, extent or purpose to the principal building/
                        structure or principal use served;
                       C.   Contributes to the comfort, convenience or necessity of occupants of the
                        principal building/structure or principal use served; and
                       D.   Is located on the same lot/parcel as the principal building/structure or
                        principal use served, except as otherwise provided in this title.
                        A facility licensed by the State as an adult daycare center or as an adult
                        respite facility, which provides care, services and supervision for less than
ADULT DAYCARE CENTER:   twenty four (24) hours a day to three (3) or more adults, who because of
                        diminished mental or physical capacity, find it difficult to care for themselves
                        in their own residence during the day. Adult daycare does not include public or
                        private school facilities or senior recreation centers.
                        A private dwelling in which a resident of the dwelling has been licensed by the
                        State to provide adult daycare home services or adult respite home services, and
                        who provides care, services and supervision for less than twenty four (24) hours
ADULT DAYCARE HOME:     a day to at least three (3) adults but not more than five (5) adults, who because
                        of diminished mental or physical capacity find it difficult to care for
                        themselves in their own residence during the day. The use as an adult daycare
                        home or adult respite home shall be an accessory use. The primary use shall be as
                        a private residence.
AGRI-BUSINESS:          A business directly supportive of an agricultural use, including agricultural
                        businesses that also incorporate entertainment and tourism.
                        Land and/or structures whose principal use includes the growing of farm crops,
AGRICULTURE:            truck garden crops, animal/poultry husbandry, dairying, floriculture, pasturage,
                        and accessory uses customarily incidental to agricultural activities, but does
                        not include feed lots, slaughterhouses, or stockyards.
                        Any landing area, runway or other facility designed, used or intended to be used,
AIRPORT:                either privately or publicly, by any person or persons for the landing and

                        down areas, hangars and other necessary buildings and open space.

CHAPTER 3
ZONING DISTRICTS AND MAP
SECTION:
9-3-1: Districts Established
9-3-2: Zoning District Map
9-3-3: Determination Of District Boundaries
9-3-4: Vacation Of Streets And Alleys
9-3-5: Zoning Of Annexed Land
9-3-1: DISTRICTS ESTABLISHED:
In order to regulate the location, height, bulk and size of buildings and other
structures, the percentage of a lot which may be occupied, the size of lots,
courts and other open spaces, the density and distribution of population, the
location and uses of land, buildings and structures for trade, industry,
residence, recreation, public activities or other purposes, the city is divided
into the following classes of districts:
SA-1       Suburban acreage, type 1
SA-2       Suburban acreage, type 2
R-1A, R-1B Single-family districts
R-2        General residential district
MH         Manufactured/mobile home district
C          Business district
M-1        Light industrial district
M-2        Heavy industrial district
P          Public use district
PUD        Planned unit development
H          Hospital
SU-1       Special use zone
 
(Ord. 969, 6-9-2015)
9-3-2: ZONING DISTRICT MAP:
The boundaries of the districts are as shown on the district map, properly
certified and on file with the city clerk where it may be inspected and
examined. (1996 Code § 17.12.020; amd. 2002 Code)
9-3-3: DETERMINATION OF DISTRICT BOUNDARIES:
Where uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of the various
districts, as shown on the district map, the following rules shall apply:
   A.   Public Ways: The district boundaries are either streets or alleys
unless otherwise shown, and where the districts designated on the zoning
district map are bounded approximately by street or alley lines, the street or
alley shall be construed to be the boundary of the district.
   B.   Lot Lines: Where the district boundaries are not otherwise indicated,
and where the property has been or is divided into blocks and lots, the
district boundaries shall be construed to be the lot lines, and where the
districts designated on the district map are bounded approximately by lot
lines, the lot lines shall be construed to be the boundary of the districts
unless the boundaries are otherwise indicated on the map.
   C.   Zoning District Map: In unsubdivided property, the district boundary
lines on the zoning district map shall be determined by use of the scale
appearing on the map. (1996 Code § 17.12.050; amd. 2002 Code)
9-3-4: VACATION OF STREETS AND ALLEYS:
Whenever the council vacates a street or alley, adjacent districts shall extend
to the centerline of the vacation. (1996 Code § 17.12.030)
9-3-5: ZONING OF ANNEXED LAND:
Prior to annexation of any land to the city, the area shall be studied by the
commission, which shall recommend to the council a zoning plan designed to
conform to the master plan of the city. Upon annexation, the lands will
automatically be zoned accordingly. (1996 Code § 17.12.040)
CHAPTER 4
PERMITTED USES
SECTION:
9-4-1: SA-1 District
9-4-2: SA-2 District
9-4-3: R-1A And R-1B Districts
9-4-4: R-2 District

9-4-6: C District

9-4-8: M-2 District
9-4-9: P District
9-4-10: H District
